Gratis.|~|Additional text in German: Sein oder nicht sein...es gibt nur eine Antwort: AIDSTEST. Anonymn gratis.|~|Additional text in French: Etre ou ne pas être...il n'y a qu'une réponse: TEST DU DESPISTAGE DU SIDA. Anonyme, gratuit.|~|Additional text in English: To be or not to be...there is only one answer: AIDSTEST. Anonymous, free of charge.
Description.note: Illustration of a positive sign (representing being HIV positive?) surrounded by an almost complete circle. Message of poster (inscribed in Letzebuergesh, German, French, and English) describes getting tested for AIDS as a life or death matter.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item LU005.

Item Title: Beste Bart, we willen even zeggen dat je bij ons moet blijven werken [inscribed]

Title: Beste Bart, we willen even zeggen dat je bij ons moet blijven werken [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Begrip En AIDS Horen Bij Elkaar.|~|Translated poster text: Listen to the concept of AIDS together.
Description.note: Poster depicts a heartfelt message of sympathy to a student who is fighting for his life. The form of a letter tells the person that others care and they want to be in contact. To understand better, be willing to learn and listen to the notion of AIDS. "dat je bij ons" on the poster is blue while the rest of the letter is written in yellow. Perhaps the letter is written by more than one student.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE004.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Ik vrij veilig of ik vrij niet.|~|Translated poster text: I rather be safe or I rather not.
Description.note: Poster has a pink rolled up condom on a silver background. Condoms are lubricated with a protective coating and are available for a useful purpose. Protection is accessible, however, using them depends on one's choice. Hence to be safe or not to be safe, is the question.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE005.

Item Title: Even aan denken [inscribed]

Description.note: Poster depicts a syringe with a red exclamation mark used for drugs. As a sign of danger, the exclamation mark emphasizes that the equipment is unsafe. Since drugs are usually hidden in large pockets of a coat, poster suggests not taking this risk.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE006.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Poster of Bodyguard magazine cover with football player wearing protective gear [descriptive]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Bodyguard.  Als je lijf je lief is pak je exemplaar van Bodyguard, de glossy over homoseks, bij horeca, sauna of GGD of bestel bij de Schorerstichting.|~|Translation of poster text: If you love your body, get your issue of Bodyguard, the magazine about homosexuality, at ... the bathhouses of the Dept of Public Health or at the main offices of Schorerstichting.

Shield logo in lower left shows condom and penis, crossed in insignia format.  Poster extends concept of wearing protective equipment for all contact sports to wearing protection for sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Item Title: Wereldwijd 13 Miljoen AIDSwezen [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: HIVOS (Organization)|~|ICCO (Organization: Netherlands)|~|Memisa (Organization : Netherlands)|~|Nederlandse Organisatie voor Internationale Bijstand|~|Aids Fonds
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wereldwijd 13 Miljoen AIDSwezen [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Miriam heeft geen vader en geen moeder meer, alleen een broer en een zus. Miljoenen aidswezen moeten zichzelf zien te redden. Stop AIDS Now! werkt aan zorg, preventie en een vaccin.|~|Translated poster text: Miriam has no father or mother and only has a brother and sister. Millions of people must try to save themselves from AIDS. Stop AIDS Now! Work for the care, prevention, and vaccine for AIDS.
Description.note: Poster publicizes the organizations that are willing to help give a future to those affected with AIDS. Three siblings in the poster are standing on a burial site looking down on the grave. Their sad expression for a great loss, is the result of this fast spreading disease.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE013.|~|Date on back of poster, 2001, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Als je later kinderen wilt: gebruik dan nu een condoom! [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Als je later kinderen wilt: gebruik dan nu een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Leder jaar worden naar schatting 1.000 vrouwen ONVRUCHTBAAR door chlamydia.|~|Translated poster text: In a tragic year, a rough estimate of 1,000 women become infertile through Chlamydia.
Description.note: Poster shows a hand holding a ring box with a condom. Background is red to express the danger of Chlamydia for women. Poster encourages using a condom now to protect a woman's ability to have children in the future.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE015.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Wil je geen soa als souvenir? Gebruik dan een condoom! [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wil je geen soa als souvenir? Gebruik dan een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Neem condooms mee op vakantie. Als je deze gebruikt, weet je zeker dat je veilig vrijt.|~|Translated poster text: Take condoms with you on a holiday. If you consistently use them, you can be sure of your safety when you go out.
Description.note: Poster recommends using a condom to prevent long term consequences (souvenir, keepsake as in the poster) of sexually transmitted diseases. Background is green to show emotional connection with safety. Poster assures one's security with the usage of protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE016.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Alternate Title.descriptive: Poster of a condom in a ringbox held in a hand

Item Title: Met syfilis ben je vatbaarder voor hiv. Gebruik daarom een condoom! [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Syphilis
Personal or Corporate Name.creator: SOA AIDS Nederland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Met syfilis ben je vatbaarder voor hiv. Gebruik daarom een condoom! [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Hiv dringt MAKKELIJKER het lichaam binnen als je een andere soa hebt.|~|Translated poster text: HIV penetrates the body MORE EASILY if you carry another STD.
Description.note: Poster informs the linkage between sexually transmitted infections and the HIV virus. HIV transmission is more likely for those infected with STIs. Therefore, the act of using a condom can prevent one and stop the risk for another.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE017.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

The poster implies that the best sex is safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE025.|~|Date on back of poster, 2000, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Viewers are directed to a web site (www.prostitutie.nl) where prostitutes, male escorts, and their customers can get more information about safe sex.

Item Title: Beter Te Laat Dan Nooit. AIDS Fonds Giro 8957 [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease) in children|~|HIV (Viruses)|~|Publicity|~|Awareness|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Family relationships|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control

Title: Beter Te Laat Dan Nooit. AIDS Fonds Giro 8957 [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Zolang Het AIDSvirus Actief is, Zijn Wij Dat Ook|~|Translated poster text: As long as the AIDS virus is active, so are we.
Description.note: Nkosi Johnson, a South African child born HIV-positive and who later developed AIDS and died at the age of 12, is shown speaking on a wireless microphone to an audience at the 13th International Conference on AIDS in Durban, South Africa. Poster's message is that it is "Better Late Than Never" to understand the dangers of AIDS. Poster implies the existence of AIDS as long as there are unprotected activities. Picture in the lower left corner is part of the AIDS Fonds banner and the picture in the lower right corner represents AIDS Memorial Day.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item NE026.
Alternate Title.translated: Better Late Than Never. AIDS Funds Giro 8957

In the top right corner, a naked man and woman are joined hand to foot to form a circle. Text in English, Norwegian, French, Russian and German along the left border of the poster gives information about preventing HIV transmission, and gives the number of an AIDS hotline. The yellow background of the poster is a photograph of male genitalia.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Item Title: VIH/SIDA: os factos [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Portugal. Commissão Nacional de Luta Contra a SIDA
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: VIH/SIDA: os factos [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: A SIDA não tem cura... Não discrimine!|~|Translated poster text: There is no cure for AIDS ... Do not discriminate!
Description.note: Poster presents the facts about the transmission of HIV and AIDS. Divided into two parts, poster presents a sequence of images to separate the facts from the misperceptions. AIDS is transmitted through: unprotected sex, contact with contaminated blood, from mother-to-child during pregnancy and breast-feeding, and sharing of needles. AIDS is not transmitted through: food or silverware, mosquito bites, coughing and sneezing, shaking hands and hugging, use of public restrooms, safe sex (condom), and social contact.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO004.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: HIV/AIDS: the facts

Title: SIDA espreita-o. Previna-se. Use preservativo [inscribed]

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PO005.

Item Title: AIDS posters collection [descriptive]
Subject.descriptiveTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--Pictorial Works|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention--Pictorial works|~|HIV infections--Pictorial works|~|AIDS (Disease)--Pictorial works|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control--Pictorial Works
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS posters collection [descriptive]
Description.abstract: Searchable database of digitized AIDS posters from 44 countries. Demonstrates the efforts taken by various countries to promote AIDS awareness and modify risk behaviors.  The physical collection was originally acquired by the History and Special Collections division of the Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library in 2005, and has been expanded through later acquisitions.

Item Title: AIDS: we are all at risk
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Papua New Guinea|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS: we are all at risk
Description.note: Top half of the poster is textual, with subheadings "How do you catch the AIDS virus?" "Why do we need to protect ourselves?" and "Let's talk about AIDS." Lower half of the poster depicts Dr. Clement Malau of the PNG National AIDS Council sitting at a desk. On the desk is a laptop computer with a map of Papua New Guinea on its screen, a microscope, and specimen tubes. The poster suggests the importance of open communication and scientific understanding of the causes and prevention of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item PP001.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.other: Protect yourself from AIDS|~|AIDS is the most serious health threat our country faces. Every month 100 Papua New Guineans will catch the AIDS virus. Our sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, wantoks are all at risk.

Después de todo, ellos son quienes mejor saben lo que significa vivir con SIDA". Kofi Annan, Secretario General de las Naciones Unidas. "Párate un momento, escucha y aprende todo lo que puedas acerca del VIH/SIDA. La prevención y la vida... ¡están en tus manos!" Joey DiPaolo, educador sobre el SIDA que vive con VIH.|~|Picture of Joey DiPaolo with Kofi Annan holding an open book titled "Living Proof."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP001.
Alternate Title.translated: I care... Do you?

Item Title: Si Da. No Da. No cambies tu vida por el SIDA [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Condoms|~|AIDS (Disease)--Risk factors|~|Awareness|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si Da. No Da. No cambies tu vida por el SIDA [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text. Si Da: Intercambiarse la maquinilla de afeitar y otros objetos personales cortantes. Transmisión de la madre al feto. Tatuaje con agujas sin esterilizar. Hacer el amor con portadores (Hombre-mujer). Relaciones homosexuales con portadores. Utilizar la misma jeringuilla. Intercambiarse el cepillo de dientes. No Da: Practicar cualquier tipo de relaciones sexuales utilizando perservativo. Bañarse con portadores. (Duchas, piscinas, etc.). Las picaduras de insectos. Jugar con portadores. Beber del mismo vaso o la misma botella. Darse la mano. Besarse and abrazarse. Cambiarse la ropa. Utilizar los mismos servicios que los portadores.|~|Images of female and male gender symbols engaging in different activities. On one side of the poster, they are depicting and describing activities that can increase the risk of transmission of the HIV virus. Activities such as having unprotected sex with a person infected with the virus, sharing needles, toothbrushes or razors. One the other half, the symbols are depicting and describing activities through which transmission is not possible or the risk of transmission is decreased. Some of these activities include having protected sex, kissing, hugging and shaking hands.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP002.
Alternate Title.translated: Yes this transmits. No this doesn't transmit. Don't change your life because of AIDS

Item Title: A mí me importa... Y a ti? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: A mí me importa... Y a ti? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: A mí me importa... Y a ti? Día mundial del SIDA. 1 de Diciembre de 2001. "No se puede saber si alguien está infectado por el VIH tan solo con mirarlo. Protegete: ponte un preservativo." Ronaldo, Embajador de Buena Voluntad del PNUD y Representante Especial para la Campaña Mundial contra el SIDA. "No es fácil hablar del SIDA si nadie te escucha. A mí me gusta escuchar." Luca, voluntario de Arché, una ONG italiana que se ocupa del SIDA.|~|Image of Ronaldo and Luca holding a soccer ball on a soccer field.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP004.
Alternate Title.translated: I care... Do you?

Item Title: Tú puedes cortar la cadena del SIDA [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Tú puedes cortar la cadena del SIDA [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Tú puedes cortar la cadena del SIDA. El SIDA es un problema de todos, podemos detener la propagación del VIH-SIDA con la prevención y la educación.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP005.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Blue letters on white background. Red and white doll cutouts holding hands. The white cutouts are wearing red AIDS ribbons.
Alternate Title.translated: You can break the AIDS chain

Item Title: A mí me importa... Y a ti? [inscribed]
Subject.descriptiveTopic: Martin, Ricky|~|Hispanic American singers|~|Volunteer workers in child welfare
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: A mí me importa... Y a ti? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Día mundial del SIDA. 1 de Diciembre de 2001. "Nuestra voz es importante. Cada uno de nosotros debe usar las aptitudes que tiene para fomentar la sensibilizacion sobre VIH/SIDA." Ricky Martin, cantante. "Escuchando a los niños jugando con ellos, viédolos sufrir, he aprendido a ser fuerte, dejando de lado la pena y el miedo." Silvia, voluntaria que trabaja con niños VIH-positivos. "Yo siempre pensaba como tú que el VIH no me afectaría nunca... hasta que di positivo." Clint Walters fundador de Health Initatives for Youth.
Description.note: Background of poster contains the image of Ricky Martin. Clint Walters and Silvia are both sitting in front of the image.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP007.
Alternate Title.translated: I care... do you?

Item Title: SIDA: hoy X hoy, la única, vacuna: información y prevención [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Comité Ciudadano Anti-SIDA Madrid|~|Madrid (Spain : Region). Servicio Regional de Salud
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: SIDA: hoy X hoy, la única, vacuna: información y prevención [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Asi no se contrae el SIDA [with depictions of how AIDS can't be contracted underneath]; Asi se previene el SIDA [with depictions of how to prevent it].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP009.|~|Poster advocates arming oneself with knowledge about preventive measures as the most effect "vaccine" against AIDS. It depicts some of the misperceptions about AIDS transmission: you can't get it by kissing, holding hands, playing with an AIDS patient, using the same utensils as an AIDS patient, or using the same toilet. It also depicts ways to prevent contracting AIDS: don't use the same razor or toothbrush, use a condom, and use unused syringes.
Alternate Title.translated: Day X Day, the only, vaccination: information and prevention

Item Title: Yo [corazón] tú; yo [condón] tú [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Spain. Ministerio de Sanidad y Consumo
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Yo [corazón] tú; yo [condón] tú [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Cada día son más los casos de hombres y mujeres afectados por el SIDA. Desgraciadamente, el SIDA existe. Afortunadament, formas de evitarlo, también. Haz tu vida normal. Y si tienes relaciones sexuales, utiliza un preservativo.
Description.note: Part of the "SIDA--Campaña para la prevención"; campaign.|~|Translation of poster text: Every day more men and women get infected by AIDS. Unfortunately, AIDS exists. Fortunately, so do methods of avoiding it. Live life as normal. And if you have sex, use a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SP010.
Alternate Title.translated: I [heart] you; I [condom] you
Alternate Title.other: I love you; I protect you|~|Yo amo tú; yo protejo tú

Item Title: Come together
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Folk hälso institutet|~|Riksförbundet för sexuell upplysning (Sweden)|~|Riksförbundet för sexuellt likaberättigande (Sweden)
Personal or Corporate Name.creator: Garbergs (Firm)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Come together
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Love question No 31, 1 av 10 kiliar tänder på andra killar. Många gör det enkelt och naturligt. Andra gör det i smyg och vågar inte bejaka sina känslor. Varken för föräldrar, vänner eller sig själva. Vem tänder du på?
Description.note: Depicts two flowers with prominent stamens, a red anthurium and a white calla lily, inclined toward each other with overprinted caption "Come together." The Swedish text in the upper left corner notes that one in ten men are turned on by other men, and that while some are openly gay, others keep their feelings and actions secret. The text then asks "Who turns you on?"|~|Part of "Love Power" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SW003.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Escludere per l'AIDS? Escluso!
Subject.conceptTopic: Mapplethorpe, Robert|~|Homosexuality, Male|~|Gay culture|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Marginality, Social|~|Haring, Keith|~|Mercury, Freddie|~|AIDS (Disease)--Switzerland
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Escludere per l'AIDS? Escluso!
Description.note: Shows a nude man floating in front of a triptych of stars, a moon, and a cloud with an angel. Below him is an assortment of items associated with gay culture (a book of Robert Mapplethorpe's photography, a Freddie Mercury album, a Keith Haring painting) as well as holiday decor and wrapped presents. The poster may represent the gifts of gay culture to the mainstream and argue against thinking of the gay community as separate and the only part of society that has to deal with AIDS. It also suggests the decimation of the gay community by AIDS, as represented by the three artists, each of whom died of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ009.
Alternate Title.translated: To exclude because of AIDS? Excluded!

Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Switzerland

Description.note: A color photograph shows a man dressed in a suit and tie seated behind a desk in an office, surrounded by shelves full of books. His closed right hand is raised with thumb pointing up in a "thumbs up" sign; on  his thumb is a condom. The word "ohne" (without) is next to the condom. The man is probably in his thirties, wears glasses, and has a professional desk job, perhaps as an archivist, lawyer or accountant. The message is that a mature, well-educated professional gay man will not have sex unless condoms are used for protection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ018.
Alternate Title.translated: Without it? Without me

Description.note: A color photograph shows a good-looking young man seated in the driver's seat of a red convertable sports car with the top down, parked on the street in front of a building in a city. His left arm rests on the top of the door, while his right arm is toward the viewer; his right hand is closed in a "thumbs up" sign, with a condom on his thumb. He wears a black leather jacket and his sunglasses are shoved back on the top of his black curley hair.  The message is that a sporty young gay man will not have sex unless condoms are used.|~|A decal on the windshield shows "92" possibly a year of registration of the automobile.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ019.
Alternate Title.translated: Without it? Without me.

Item Title: Wir schützen uns, weil wir uns lieben
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Wir schützen uns, weil wir uns lieben
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Eine Präventionskampagne des Bundesamtes für Gesundheitswesen, in Zusammenarbeit mit der Aids Hilfe Schweiz.|~|SEILER DDB NEEDHAM/cR
Description.note: Two muscular young men, clad only in undershorts and shorts, are enjoying a picnic in a grain field.  In the foreground, one man lies on his back on a blanket, shorts open in front and pulled down to reveal his undershorts. He holds hands and looks fondly into the face of his lover, who is sitting up next to him, dressed only in undershorts.  Their eyes display love for each other.  An open picnic basket sits nearby, and one can see some bread, some wine, some watermelon, and some red condoms. The scene is one of idyllic pleasure, and also of safety and security.|~|Part of "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ020.
Alternate Title.translated: We protect each other, because we love one another

Item Title: Nous nous protégeons parce que nous nous aimons
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control

Description.note: A color photograph shows a man and a woman playfully relaxing in a small boat, secluded by some reeds at the edge of a large lake. The man, dressed in undershorts, is leaning back on a bench in the boat, looking at the woman and teasing her by dangling her bra from one outstretched hand.  The woman is facing him, seated on another bench, and is splashing him with a little water from the lake. She is covered by some clothing draped from breast to hips. Next to the man is a straw bag draped with an article of clothing; on top are seen two red unopened condoms.  The scene is one of sexy playfulness, love, fun, safety and security because the man uses condoms for protection.|~|Part of "Stop AIDS" campaign|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ021.
Alternate Title.translated: We protect each other because we love one another

Item Title: Ich habe Aids. Ich habe Angst vor Ihrer Angst vor mir
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ich habe Aids. Ich habe Angst vor Ihrer Angst vor mir
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Die Solidaritätskampagne der Aids-Hilfe Schweiz, in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Bundesamt für Gesundheitswesen.
Description.note: A black and white photo in which a young man stands alone against an empty background, on the right side of the photo. He wears jeans, a long sleeved shirt with open collar, and a vest open at the front.  With dark hair and a large dark moustache, he looks dolefully toward the viewer, left hand placed on his waist, right hand in his jeans pocket. The photo evokes a sombre mood of lonliness and fear, which encourages to viewer to think about being in the same state as the young man, and emphasizes the need to stop AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ026.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: I have AIDS. I'm afraid of the fear you have of me

Item Title: En tant qu'homme malade du Sida ne suis-je plus qu'un malade du Sida?
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Social networks
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: En tant qu'homme malade du Sida ne suis-je plus qu'un malade du Sida?
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Campagne de prévention de l'Aide Suisse contre le SIDA, en collaboration avec l'Office fédéral de la santé publique.
Description.note: A black and white photograph in the center of which stands a man looking directly at the viewer, his left hand in his trousers pocket, with a thoughtful, inquiring, and vaguely challenging look on his face.  He is nicely  dressed in slacks and a long-sleeved sweater, just an ordinary man aged in his thirties, balding in front, with a goatee and moustache.  His challenge is to be seen as an individual human being, not just a sick man with AIDS.|~|Part of the "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ027.
Alternate Title.translated: In my capacity as a man sick with Aids, am I nothing more than just a sick man with AIDS?

Item Title: Präservative stoppen AIDS

The face on the left is a woman, indicated by a groomed eyebrow and by eyeshadow above the eye; the eye on the left is a man's eye with a bushy eyebrow.  The "o" in the title word "stoppen" is a pink condom. The message is that condoms prevent the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Item Title: Blocca l'AIDS. Non cominciare.
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Blocca l'AIDS. Non cominciare.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Campagna di prevenzione dell'AIUTO AIDS SVIZZERO, in collaborazione con l'Ufficio federale della sanità pubblica.|~|cR Basel
Description.note: A closeup color photograph of two faces very close together, where only one eye from each face is seen. The face on the left has fair skin and a blue eye, that on the right has dark skin and a dark eye. In between the faces is the tip of a syringe, held up by one of the people, with both eyes focused upon it. The message is that sharing needles can transmit AIDS; do not share needles.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ033.
Alternate Title.translated: Stop AIDS. Don't start.

Item Title: ...mit Gebrauchten nie!

The message emphasizes that one way to stop AIDS is to never share needles.|~|Part of the "Stop AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Item Title: Sie steht für ein neues Gefühl...
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Communication
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sie steht für ein neues Gefühl...
Description.inscription: Partial poster text: Sie steht für ein neues Gefühl: lustvoller Sex, ohne Angst. Sie steht für Verantwortung ... Solidarität ... Vertrauen ... offene Gesprächsbereitschaft. Symbol für Sicherheit; safer sex.|~|Aids-Hilfe Schweiz, Aide Suisse contre le SIDA, Aiuto AIDS Svizzero, Postfach 7660, CH-8023, Zürich
Description.note: A safety pin is shown pinned onto the lapel of a man's suit. The poster image is a black and white photo showing the left-hand side of a man's torso, from his chin to his shoulder; he is wearing a tie, a shirt with button-down collar, and a suit. Vertically along the right side of the poster are five olive-yellow boxes containing the texts, with a little safety pin image next to each one.  What the safety pin stands for are: new feelings, responsibility, solidarity, trust, and open verbal communication. If a man practices safe sex, his wearing of the safety pin would let others know that they can talk with him about it.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item SZ037.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: How AIDS is spread
Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How AIDS is spread
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS is spread mainly through sexual intercourse with an infected person. AIDS is spread through blood contaminated instruments. AIDS is spread through infected woman during pregnancy to her unborn child. AIDS is spread through infected blood transfusion. Prevent AIDS! Have sexual intercourse with a faithful partner for life. Accept medical treatment only from trained health workers in health centres where equipment is kept sterile and blood is checked against AIDS.|~|Poster is item 7 in Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.note: Poster describes four ways by which AIDS is spread: sexual intercourse, contaminated medical instruments, pregnancy and blood transfusions. Illustrations depict a naked man and woman in silhouette, a man receiving medical treatment from a traditional healer, a kneeling pregnant woman, and a woman receiving a blood transfusion.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG001.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Item Title: What does a person with AIDS look like? AIDS can look like many other diseases. Don't be confused. Don't spread rumors
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What does a person with AIDS look like? AIDS can look like many other diseases. Don't be confused. Don't spread rumors
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS or measles? AIDS or tuberculosis? AIDS or alcoholism? AIDS or malnutrition? AIDS or typhoid? AIDS or cancer? See a qualified medical person for tests if you think you or someone you know may have AIDS.|~|Item 5 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.note: Illustrations depict 6 other diseases or conditions that can easily be misidentified as AIDS. Poster suggests that people should not assume that someone has AIDS just because they appear sick, and the importance of testing for people who suspect they have AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG002.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Item Title: What have you heard about AIDS? Don't guess the answers! Learn the truth about AIDS!
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you heard about AIDS? Don't guess the answers! Learn the truth about AIDS!
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: What does it mean? What can we do for people who have it? How does it harm us? Can it be cured? Who can get it? What does it look like? What causes it? Which of us has it? How can we stop it?|~|Item 3 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.note: Illustration depicts a young girl and boy walking. The girl is whispering in the boy's ear. Poster suggests that children should learn the facts about AIDS rather than spreading misinformation.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG003.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Item Title: Care for people with AIDS : protect your patients from infections, protect yourself and others from AIDS
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Care for people with AIDS : protect your patients from infections, protect yourself and others from AIDS
Description.inscription: Item 10 in the Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.note: Illustration depicts a man in a sick bed with a woman and child caring for him. Additional illustrations show 4 ways to prevent the transmission of AIDS: washing hands, covering wounds, keeping the patient clean and not sharing sharp instruments like razors.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG004.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Item Title: You can not get AIDS from...prevent AIDS. Learn the ways it can and cannot spread. AIDS is not spread in the ways shown above.
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You can not get AIDS from...prevent AIDS. Learn the ways it can and cannot spread. AIDS is not spread in the ways shown above.
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS is spread through sexual intercourse with an infected person, through blood contaminated instruments, through infected women to their unborn children and through infected blood transfusions.|~|Item 8 of Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control
Description.note: Illustrations depict four ways AIDS is not spread: contact such as holding hands or kissing, sharing clothing and combs, sharing cups or utensils, or from insects or animals. Poster suggests that people should educate themselves about how AIDS is spread.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG005.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Item Title: Previnase do SIDA
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Previnase do SIDA
Description.inscription: Caption: Tenha relações sexuais somente com um parceiro que lhe seja fiel. Só aceite tratamento médico do pessoal de saúde qualificado.|~|Translation: Have sexual relations with a faithful sex partner. Get medical treatment only from trained health care workers.
Description.note: Poster depicts a happy family together. A baby held by its mother is receiving a shot from a health care worker, a member of the "ministry of health," as indicated on label on medical bag. Health care worker is using sterile medical supplies.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG006.
Alternate Title.translated: Prevent AIDS

Item Title: Can you spot which person carries HIV? The answer is no!
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: UNICEF|~|Uganda. Ministry of Education|~|AIDS Control Programme (Uganda)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Can you spot which person carries HIV? The answer is no!
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: The AIDS virus can hide in a person's blood for many years. People who carry AIDS may look and feel healthy, but they can still give AIDS to others!|~|Adapted from Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control (Item 5).
Description.note: Illustration depicts 9 people standing together, male and female, young and old. Text suggests that we shouldn't assume someone isn't infected just because they look healthy.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UG007.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Uganda School Health Kit on AIDS Control

Item Title: Don't mess up, dress up! [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Safe Sex
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Durex Information Service for Sexual Health
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Don't mess up, dress up! [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Nowadays, when you have sex, you need to protect yourself. Condoms are the only sure way of reducing the risks of unplanned pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases… including HIV/AIDS. You can buy condoms from chemists, supermarkets, petrol stations and vending machines. There’s more to condoms than you think—check out the instructions next time you buy a pack.
Description.note: Purple background with yellow and light purple text. Cartoons of two personified penises. One penis has a worried expression; the other is covered by a condom and is smiling, winking, and making a thumbs-up sign. Lower right corner shows logo for Durex, a brand of condoms. Poster humorously promotes the use of condoms for safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK001.

Item Title: What am I? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually Transmitted Diseases--therapy|~|Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|Sexually Transmitted Diseases--diagnosis
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What am I? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: I’m free ‘n’ easy and fun to pick up. I’m easily passed on. I can be invisible and damage your health. I’m a sexually transmitted disease. Most STIs are easily treated, but if left can cause serious health problems. Regular check-ups are recommended to detect STIs which may go unnoticed.
Description.note: Background stripes of pink, green, purple, and blue; text in white & black. Depicts four rows of curios. Row 1: drawing of Freud's profile with naked man as face; toothbrush with popsicle on stick; pineapple filled with ice; bear sculpture with banana as tail. Row 2: "Ken" doll; ceramic teapot shaped as cottage; photo of gnome and pink flamingo lawn decorations; greeting card with picture of cowboy. Row 3: hand grenade; pen with photo of nude man; pastille candies with red hearts. Row 4: Bandages of the invisible man; green & blue bugs; mer-man.|~|Sponsors: Community HIV and AIDS Prevention Strategy; Gay Men’s Project; Slap fM; Gay Men Fighting AIDS; Healthy Gay Manchester; Gay Men's Health Matters; BIGUP; Yorkshire MESMAC; Naz Project London; The Network.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. George House Trust, established in 1985 (as "Manchester AIDSline"), is one of the oldest HIV charities in the UK.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK015.|~|Date on back of poster, 1999, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: When Martin was told he had AIDS, his family couldn't believe it. After all, he is 64 [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: When Martin was told he had AIDS, his family couldn't believe it. After all, he is 64 [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Not surprisingly they came to us. Still numb. Still protesting that they thought AIDS was only a 'young person's' illness. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. We're now helping them accept Martin's illness and carry on with their lives. Old or young. Him or her. White or black. Straight or gay. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.
Description.note: Black and white photograph of three smiling people sitting on a blanket in the grass: a middle-aged man and woman, and a young man. Poster suggests that anyone can be infected with AIDS, not just young gay men, and describes London Lighthouse as a resource for older people who are HIV-positive.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK016.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Their son was diagnosed HIV+. Their son went to them for support. Their son was told he wasn't their son anymore. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Services for|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Social networks|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Family relationships|~|Counseling
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Their son was diagnosed HIV+. Their son went to them for support. Their son was told he wasn't their son anymore. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Then, their son came to us. He told us his story. We listened. We explained that his parents weren't evil. Just ignorant. Overwhelmed by fear. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. In fact, his parents are now talking to us. Which is a start. Straight or gay. Old or young. White or black. Him or her. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a smiling middle-aged couple holding a "Happy Anniversary" cake with lit candles. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive people even when their families reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK017.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: She told her husband she was HIV+. He took it badly. She told her best friends. They took off [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: She told her husband she was HIV+. He took it badly. She told her best friends. They took off [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: She told us. We listened. And listened. She told us she'd spent her life caring for others and that now, when she really needed hope, there was no-one. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. By the way, she left her husband and is now rebuilding her life again. Her or him. Young or old. Gay or straight. Black or white. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a woman's face reflected in a mirror. She has a black eye. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive women whose families and friends reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK018.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Amy's dad couldn't bring himself to accept he had AIDS. Now he can. He just can't bring himself to tell her. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Amy's dad couldn't bring himself to accept he had AIDS. Now he can. He just can't bring himself to tell her. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Could you? Probably not. That's why he came to us. We didn't tell Amy for him though. We just helped him find the strength to tell her himself. That's how we work. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. Amy doesn't understand yet, but one day, she will. Young or old. Him or her. Black or white. Straight or gay. AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a man holding a young girl. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for HIV-positive men with families.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK019.|~|Date on back of poster, 1995, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Derek lost his entire family to AIDS. One year later, they're still not talking to him. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Derek lost his entire family to AIDS. One year later, they're still not talking to him. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: That's why he called us. We always listen. We never judge. We know that family rejection can sometimes be more distressing than the illness. That's why London Lighthouse provides information, care and support for anyone affected by HIV and AIDS. We're still trying to help Derek's family understand. Black or white. Him or her. Young or old. Straight or gay, AIDS doesn't care. We do. We need you to as well.
Description.note: Black and white photograph of a bald man with his back to the viewer, talking on a telephone. Poster describes London Lighthouse as a resource for people with AIDS when their families reject them.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK020.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Bhangra against homophobia [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bhangra against homophobia [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1 in 4 Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual people experience homophobic violence and harassment. Discrimination on the grounds of sexuality is a violation of human rights. Silence reinforces homophobic attitudes. Don't be part of the problem.
Description.note: Black and white photograph of 2 Indian women embracing. Poster suggests the importance of speaking up against homophobia and discrimination based on sexuality, and provides contact information for 3 organizations that can provide information about sexuality and safer sex: Kiss (a Naz Project London), the Metro Centre (a centre for lesbian, gay and bisexual people), and Shakti (South Asian Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transexual Network).|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK021.

Item Title: Si él no tiene un condón, pídele que busque uno
Subject.conceptTopic: Communication and sex|~|Safe Sex|~|Condom use|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si él no tiene un condón, pídele que busque uno
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: No es lo más fácil de decir. Pero en estos tiempos, tienes que hacerlo. Los condones pueden protegerte, si los usas apropiadamente y cada vez que haces el amor. Si estás saliendo con alguien que no le gusta usar condones, háblale antes de hacer el amor. Dále tu opinión acerca de esto. Y ayudálo en esa situación incómoda. Pero si todaviá se niega a usarlos, preguntate si vale la pena correr el riesgo. America responde al SIDA.
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign. Picture of a young girl sitting on a chair.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US002.
Alternate Title.translated: If he doesn't have a condom, ask him to find one.

Item Title: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Intravenous drug abuse|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Sexual abstinence
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: There's a simple way to prevent AIDS. You want to be risk-free from AIDS? Don't have sex.  And as long as you aren't shooting drugs, you'll be fine. No worries about who's slept around, who's had blood tests, and whether your condoms are latex or not.
Description.note: Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign. Picture of a woman sitting on a chair with her legs crossed. The concept of the poster is to promote abstinence from sex and drug use as an effective way to avoid the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US003.

Item Title: What have you got against a condom? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you got against a condom? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: What have you got against a condom? The simple act of putting on a condom can save your life, if they're used properly and every time you have sex. For more information about AIDS and condoms, call 1-800-342-AIDS.
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS". The poster is a picture of a woman.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US004.

Item Title: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Why alcohol, crack and other drugs can put you at risk for the AIDS virus. They cloud your thinking. You already know that shooting up drugs and sharing needles put you at risk for AIDS. But actually, other drugs such as crack, alcohol and marijuana can put you at risk because they cloud your thinking. And when your thinking is clouded, you take foolish chances. When you're high, you may have sex. That's risky stuff. So think clearly. Don't risk AIDS. If you'd like more information on the relationship between AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, call the National AIDS hotline. 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY.
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|The poster is a blurry image of two people.  It implies that drug and alcohol use can impaire the mind, leading to behavior that puts one at risk of HIV infection.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US005.

Description.note: Image of two men, one is embracing the other and holding a condom in one hand.  The poster implies that whether either man is HIV positive or negative, they are doing the safe thing by protecting themselves with a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US006.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: American Council of Life Insurance|~|American Red Cross|~|Health Insurance Association of America
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: See beyond fear. You can't get AIDS- by shaking hands, or by hugging, in restaurants, or in restrooms. AIDS doesn't spread through casual contact. Don't let fear get in the way of facts. Take the time to learn about AIDS.
Description.note: Black, white and red poster with pixtures of two people shaking hands, hugging, a served plate and a mens and womens restroom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US007.

Item Title: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually Transmitted Diseases--prevention & control|~|Unsafe sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Poster text: Why there's a connection between sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS. Simple. The same type of sexual behavior that can infect you with gonorrhea, gential herpes, syphilis, and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) can also infect you with something else... the AIDS virus. You get STDs by having sex with someone who is infected. That's bad enough. But if you continue the same unprotected sexual behavior, you could get something you can't cure. AIDS. If you'd like more information on the relationship between AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, call the National AIDS hotline. 1-800-342-AIDS. The hotline for the hearing impaired is 1-800-AIDS-TTY.
Description.note: Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign. The poster depicts a young man leaning into his open school locker. He is holding two books in his hands.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US008.

Subject.conceptTopic: Drug abuse|~|AIDS (Disease)--Risk factors|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Sex
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Huellas peligrosas [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Ana está saliendo con un chico que se inyecta drogas. Ella está cometiendo un error grave. El puede adquirir el SIDA por compartir las agujas de las jeringas. Ana podría adquirir el SIDA por culpa de él. Ella tiene varias opciones: Hacer que él deje de inyectase drogas o buscarle ayuda profesional y tratamiento contra las drogas; u olvidarse de él, o por lo menos asegurarse que cuando tienen relaciones sexuales, él use un condón.
Description.note: Depicts the arms of a couple holding hands. His arm shows needle marks from intravenous drug use. Poster suggests a relationship with risks: intravenous drug use, unprotected sex.|~|Part of "America responde al SIDA" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US012.
Alternate Title.translated: Dangerous tracks

Item Title: What have you got against a condom? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Helplines--United States|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Safe Sex|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What have you got against a condom? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: The simple act of putting on a condom can save your life, if they're used properly and every time you have sex. For more information about AIDS and condoms, call 1-800-342-AIDS.
Description.note: A black and white close-up portrait of a good-looking well-dressed African American woman; she looks intently at the viewer as she delivers this message.|~|Part of the "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US013.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: You won't get AIDS in a restaurant [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You won't get AIDS in a restaurant [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS is a virus that is not spread through day-to-day contact. For more information about AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS.
Description.note: A colored drawing of a waiter's arm and hand holding up a clear glass dish of lettuce and tomato salad on a serving tray.|~|Part of the "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US014.

Item Title: You won't get AIDS from hide 'n' seek [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You won't get AIDS from hide 'n' seek [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDS is a virus that is not spread through day-to-day contact. For more information about AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS.
Description.note: On a light green background, a boy chases a girl in a spirited game of hide and seek.  The colored drawing depicts a white, blond pre-teen or teen-aged boy in jeans shorts, a yellow shirt and blue sneakers, smiling and running with arms outstretched after a girl of about the same age.  She is dressed in colorful pants, jacket and shirt, with blond hair in pigtails flying as she runs, smiling, in front of the boy.  The image is one of youthful fun, energy and innocence, without fear of catching the AIDS virus.|~|Part of the "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US015.

Item Title: You won't get AIDS from a bug bite [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: You won't get AIDS from a bug bite [inscribed]

Description.note: On a light green background is a large color drawing of an insect that resembles a mosquito, illustrating the poster's message that you cannot contract AIDS from a bug bite.|~|Part of the "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US016.

Item Title: Don't listen to rumors about AIDS. Get the facts!
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: American Red Cross|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Don't listen to rumors about AIDS. Get the facts!
Description.inscription: Know for sure how you can get it and how you can't. Call 1-800-342-AIDS.|~|Photography by Lennon The Photographer. American Red Cross, Stock No. 329510 (Formerly Poster 1903)[Lower left corner:] (R) GCIU 846
Description.note: Headshot of Patti La Belle, well known rhythm and blues singer, successful in the United States since the 1960s. La Belle is supporting education about the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US017.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Stops transmission-fluid leaks
Personal or Corporate Name.creator: McElhaney, Jeff
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Stops transmission-fluid leaks
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Recently, top researchers filled condoms with AIDS virus-infected fluid and subjected them to pressure tests for three weeks.  No virus leaked through.  The fact of life here: Wearing condoms stops AIDS from spreading.  So try out this newfound bit of carnal knowledge: Using a condom can save your life.
Description.note: Poster depicts a black and white photograph of a used, stretched out condom. The image of the condom connects to the title to suggest the importance of a condom as prevention to the transmission of AIDS.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US018.
Alternate Title.other: Use condoms. There's living proof they stop AIDS
Alternate Title.descriptive: [Condom] stops transmission-fluid leaks

Item Title: Tres razones para no andar en la calle con los muchachos
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Tres razones para no andar en la calle con los muchachos
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Yo creía que tenía que salir con otras mujeres para pasar un buen rato. Hasta que me di cuenta que estaba arriesgando a mi familia. Es que, el SIDA está allí...|~|NAIEP 10/91 P094
Description.note: A black and white family portrait of a latino husband and wife with their two young children, a boy and a girl. They smile happily, giving the sense of a closeknit and loving family. The intention is to make men think hard about the risks of going out with their friends and having sex with women of the streets. They could bring AIDS back to their family.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US019.
Alternate Title.translated: Three reasons not to go out on the street with the guys

Item Title: Getting high doesn't cause AIDS. It just lets it happen
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Getting high doesn't cause AIDS. It just lets it happen
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Find out more about how drug use and AIDS are related. Call the National AIDS hotline at 1-800-342-AIDS.|~|NAIEP P145. U.S. Government Printing Office 1993-0-738-391
Description.note: A black and white photograph of a clean cut young black man and woman sitting on a rooftop. The woman is in the man's lap and his arms are encircled about her. They both wear jackets, and they are staring into the distance, looking ahead and not at one another.  The message is that taking drugs can lead to unsafe sexual behavior that may result in sharing the AIDS virus.|~|Part of the "American responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US020.

Item Title: If he doesn't have a condom, you just have to take a deep breath and tell him to go get one

Title: If he doesn't have a condom, you just have to take a deep breath and tell him to go get one
Description.inscription: Additional partial poster text: It's not the easiest thing in the world to say. But these days, you have to...|~|NAIEP Inv. #105
Description.note: A black and white photograph of an attractive black woman who is lounging on a couch. She is dressed in a blouse with an open collar and woven slacks. Her facial expression is firm as she encourages other women to talk about condoms with their dates.  She asks whether it is worth the risk if the man does not agree to use one.|~|Part of "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US021.

Title: How about dinner, a movie, and a talk about AIDS?
Description.note: Poster depicts a young woman. Along the right side of the poster is the text of a conversation between an imagined interviewer and "Marie," apparently the pictured woman. The conversation is about Marie feeling it is important to talk about AIDS with "guys," i.e. potential sex partners.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US023.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: AIDS does not discriminate
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS does not discriminate
Description.inscription: Poster text: AIDS does not discriminate. Anyone can get AIDS from sexual contact or sharing needles with an infected person. But we know how to prevent AIDS. Learn how to protect yourself. Call 1-800-541-AIDS.
Description.note: Poster shows a picture of nine people from different walks of life, of different ages and races, under the words "AIDS does not discriminate."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US024.|~|Date on back of poster, 1996, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: AIDS is a deadly disease caused by HIV...
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: AIDS is a deadly disease caused by HIV...
Description.inscription: AIDS is a deadly disease caused by HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus). To avoid infection through sex, don't have sex, or have sex only with a partner who isn't infected. An infected woman can pass HIV to her baby during pregnancy or when the baby is being born. HIV is spread by sharing needles...|~|Additional text: AIDS: facts for life
Description.note: Poster consists of a list of facts about AIDS and AIDS transmission.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US025.|~|Date on back of poster, 2002, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: You won't get AIDS from a public pool
Description.inscription: Part of the "America responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|AIDS is a virus that is not spread through day-to-day contact. For more information about AIDS, call 1-800-342-AIDS.
Description.note: Poster depicts beach ball on a sky blue background with the words "You won't get AIDS from a public pool" in front of it.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US026.

Item Title: Respect yourself protect yourself
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Respect yourself protect yourself
Description.inscription: African-American HIV/AIDS Program: Contact your local chapter for information. American Red Cross
Description.note: Poster depicts the African continent striped in red, green, and yellow, in front of a black background. In front of it are the words "Respect yourself protect yourself."|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US027.

Item Title: Preocupándote del HIV no es suficiente. Más vale hacer algo
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Centers for Disease Control (U.S.)|~|United States. Public Health Service
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Preocupándote del HIV no es suficiente. Más vale hacer algo
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Si crees que estás a riesgo de estar infectado con el HIV, ahora es el momento de pensar en buscar la asesoría y hacerte examinar. Si tu resultado es positivo, trabaja junto con un médico para tomar las decisiones que serán las mehores para tí. Cuanto más rápido lo hagas, más le ayudará la atención médica. Consulta con un médico, con su departamento de salud o los otros centros locales para el SIDA. Llama al teléfono especial para el SIDA de su estado o zona local, o al teléfono nacional al 1-800-344-7432. Para las personas con impedimentos del oído, llama al 1-800-243-7889 (TTY). HIV es el virus que causa el SIDA.
Description.note: Poster depicts the face of a pensive man.|~|Part of "America Responds to AIDS" campaign.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US028.|~|Date on back of poster, 1994, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Worrying about HIV is not sufficient. You have to do something|~|America responds to AIDS

Title: Woman in sweater,
