Title: Creemos en Dios.  Creemos que el sexo es sagrado.  Creemos en cuidar el uno al otro.  Creemos en el uso del condón. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Good Catholics use condoms; www.condoms4life.org; Catholics For A Free Choice.|~|Translated poster text: Good Catholics use condoms; www.condoms4life.org; Catholics For A Free Choice.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US046.|~|Poster shows a black and white photo of a couple hugging and smiling.  Poster suggests that good Catholics not only maintain their core religious beliefs, they also use condoms.
Alternate Title.translated: We believe in God.  We believe that sex is sacred.  We believe in caring for each other.  We believe in using condoms.

Item Title: Rischio AIDS? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: HIV Infections--therapy|~|HIV infections--Diagnosis|~|HIV infections--Treatment|~|Home care services--Italy|~|Hotlines (Communication)--Italy|~|AIDS (Disease)--Italy
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Servizio tossicodipendenze (Verona, Italy). Sezione di screening HIV|~|Centro di medicina preventiva (Verona, Italy)|~|ULSS 20 Verona
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Rischio AIDS? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Pronto Gruppo C. Helpline 045 86.222.32. Informazioni, test, therapie antiHIV, assistenza domiciliare.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT008.|~|The words Pronto Gruppo C (Group C is ready) stand out against a colorful but indistinct background. The "C" is prominent at the top of the poster, a white letter inside a solid red circle. One can see a group of faces looking upward to the right.  The Gruppo C helpline is available for information about AIDS, testing, anti-HIV drug therapy, and home health care assistance.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS risk?

Item Title: Infezione da virus dell'AIDS? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Progetto di ricerca AIDS|~|ULSS 25 Region Veneto|~|Istituto superiore di sanità (Italy)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Infezione da virus dell'AIDS? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Stop AIDS. Ci preoccupiamo della tua salute, non della tua identità. Esami in anonimato, un medico al telefono, analisi gratuite.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT009.|~|The background of the black-and-white poster consists of 25 thumbnail images, each of which is a drawing of an individual person talking into a telephone. There are 8 different drawings, some of which are repeated. They depict one woman and several men; their clothing is characteristic of their status: professional worker, blue-colar worker, student. The drawings illustrate that people from all genders and walks of life can call this health network and speak anonymously with a physician about their AIDS-related health issues, and receive free medical advice and testing. In the center of the poster is a large letter C on a blue background.  The telephone number, the Stop AIDS slogan, and the Gruppo C name are lettered in red. All other lettering is in white over a black background.|~|Translated poster text: Stop AIDS. We worry about your health, not your identity. Anonymous, a doctor on the telephone, free testing.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Abstinence has a high failure rate. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Catholics for a Free Choice (Organization)|~|Public Media Center (U.S.)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Abstinence has a high failure rate. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: People of faith use condoms; www.condoms4life.org; Catholics for a free choice.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item US047.|~|Poster shows black and white photo of a man lying on his back on a couch and a woman lying on top of him.  They are embracing and looking at the viewer with a surprised expression on their faces.  Poster suggests that most people are not going to abstain from sex, so they should use condoms.  It also states that religious people use condoms.

Item Title: Dalla solidarietà la prevenzione [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Progetto di ricerca AIDS|~|ULSS 25 Region Veneto|~|Italy. Ministero della sanità|~|Istituto superiore di sanità (Italy)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Dalla solidarietà la prevenzione [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Se la paura ci divide, l'AIDS cresce.  Progetto di ricerca AIDS 1990 - Ministero della sanità Istituto superiore di sanità; ULSS 25 Verona, Regione Veneto; 045-30843 Gruppo C. "Project 045/6300214" is inscribed along the right hand edge of the poster.|~|Translated poster text: From solidarity comes prevention.  If fear divides us, AIDS continues to grow.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT013.|~|The text on this poster appears on an illustration that resembles a mirror-image Rorschach ink-blot design, with the top half mirrored on the bottom (which is upside-down).  The design suggests a group of people, and is colored with a watercolor wash of orange, green and brown shades. The top group of people is divided from the upside-down bottom group, illustrating the message that if fear divides us, AIDS will grow. At the bottom of the poster appears a logo: two telephone receivers with a red drop of blood in between them.

Item Title: Stop AIDS [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Temptation|~|Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Young adults|~|Condoms|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Condoms--utilization
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: ULSS 25 Verona|~|Banca popolare di Novara|~|Leo Club Scaligero
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Stop AIDS [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated poster text: "Youth against AIDS" an initiative of the Lion Club of Verona. AIDS information 045-8030843 - Gruppo C - ULSS 25. Peoples' Bank of Novara, Verona Branch.|~|Additional poster text: "I giovani contro l'AIDS" un'iniziativa del Leo Club Scaligero. Informazioni AIDS 045-8030843 - Gruppo C - ULSS 25. Banca Popolare di Novara - Succursale di Verona.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT014.|~|A pen-and-ink drawing of an attractive and alluring young woman, who looks the viewer straight in the face and who holds a condom out towards you.  In the background are a full moon and a serpent, symbols of the night and passion and temptation. Underneath the drawing are the words, "La Prudenza" or Prudence. The woman draws the viewer to her, but indicates that it is necessary to take prudent measures and have safe sex. Part of a "Stop AIDS" campaign.

Item Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: No sex.  No home.    That's the choice I face.  I know this can make me vulnerable to HIV.  But if I want a home and my family secure, it is hard to say no to my husband's demands.  This has to change.     Equality for women helps fight AIDS.
Description.note: Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|~|Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: In small print on bottom left of poster: The text on this poster does not necessarily represent the situation, opinions, views or beliefs of the person depicted.|~|Additional text: I am a mother, daughter, sister, partner, friend. I run a home. I work, feed my family, bring up my children. I keep us smiling. I am HIV positive and I live in your community. To keep doing all this, I need your support and respect. Equality for women helps fight AIDS.|~|www.worldaidscampaign.org; womenandaids.org; www.unaids.org
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA011.|~|Poster depicts a woman from the waist up, leaning against a wall and wearing a striped t-shirt and a scarf. She is smiling at the viewer. The space over her head and below her waist is in shadow. Although women account for half of the people infected with HIV or AIDS, poster implies that they often don't have a voice. Promoting equal rights for women will help in the fight against AIDS.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Be free [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|Sexually Transmitted Diseases--prevention & control|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|HIV infections--Diagnosis|~|AIDS (Disease)--Italy
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Gruppo C |~|Progetto Sirio|~|Azienda Ulss 20 di Verona
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Be free [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 045 8622232, information AIDS, test HIV in anonimato. I rapporti sessuali non protetti sono un rischio per la salute. Chiama il Gruppo C del Centro di Medicina Preventiva. Solo sesso sicuro.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT010.|~|The poster depicts a drawing of a blue, old-fashioned dial telephone, on a blue background which incorporates the words, "solo sesso sicuro." Into the design of the phone dial are integrated the signs for male and female; the holes in the dial show the numbers for the hotline telephone number.  The theme of this poster is that safe sex prevents the risk of AIDS, and that more information about AIDS as well as free, anonymous HIV testing are available by calling Gruppo C's hotline number.|~|Translated additional poster text: AIDS information, anonymous HIV testing. Unprotected sexual relations are a risk to your health.  Call Grouppo C of the Centro de Medicina Preventiva.  Safe sex only.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Women--Health and welfare|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Women's rights
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: No respect.  No hope.  Many of us do not command enough rights or respect in our communities.  We are more likely to face sexual violence and can't find jobs or own property so easily.  This makes us more vulnerable to HIV.  This has to change.  Equality for women helps fight AIDS.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA015.|~|Photograph of a woman, probably of South Asian descent, looking towards but not directly at the viewer.

Item Title: Test HIV [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Italy. Ministero della sanità|~|Gruppo C, Network Italiano
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Test HIV [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Fare il test e'importante per te e per gli altri. Stop AIDS, Progetto del Ministero della Sanità, ex Secedas. In collaborazione con Gruppo C Network Italiano.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item IT012.|~|Underneath the title, "Test HIV," is a large black arrow pointing downwards to words which translated reads, "Getting the test is important for you and for others."Along the left side of the poster in white lettering on a blue background is a textual explanation of how AIDS is transmitted (sharing needles, from sexual relations, from an infected mother to her baby). Also explained is the need to take a simple blood test, and advice about how it is voluntary and anonymous to do so; the results are confidential. Finally there is the warning that many people have contact with HIV without knowing it.

Item Title: VIH [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: France. Ministère des solidarités, de la santé et de la famille|~|Institut national de prévention et d'éducation pour la santé (France)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: VIH [inscribed]
Description.inscription: In left-hand corner: BETC Euro RSCG 3112-06279-A.|~|Logos at bottom of poster include Ministère de la Santé et des Solidarités, INPES, Sida Info Service, www.havefun.fr.|~|Additional poster text: Traitement post-exposition. En cas d'exposition possible au VIH, vous avez 48 heures pour vous rendre auz urgences d'un hôpital et réduire le risque de contamination.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR112.|~|Translation of additional poster text: Post-exposure treatment. In case of possible exposure to HIV, you have 48 hours to go to a hospital emergency room and reduce the risk of contaminiation.|~|Poster has a black background with white lettering, within whach is a running figure.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: HIV

Item Title: These are some of the most painful symptoms of HIV and AIDS. Help us fight fear, shame, ignorance and injustice worldwide. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention--Moral and ethical aspects.|~|HIV infections--Social aspects
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Title: These are some of the most painful symptoms of HIV and AIDS. Help us fight fear, shame, ignorance and injustice worldwide. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Next to the UNAIDS slogan there is this sentence: Live and let live.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items UNA010_2 and UNA010_1 (back).|~|The poster shows a picture of different people with different ethnicities and different ages are talking with no fear about the people who have AIDS and HIV. Some of the examples of what these people said: "You're fired", "I don't want to hear about that", "Stay away", "you bastard", "I'm leaving you", "you're an unclean woman", "you've brought shame on your family", "we can't give you medication", "you're already dead", "the wedding is off", "I'm sorry but we can't come", "don't touch anything", "I loved you", "I thought you loved us", etc...

Item Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|~|Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Have you heard me today? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: No Sex.  No school.     That's the choice I face.  I know this makes me vulnerable to HIV but many of us can only afford to go to school by allowing our bodies to be used.  This has to change.     Equality for women helps fight AIDS
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA014.|~|Image of a young woman in her teens, of African descent and wearing a headscarf, looking directly at the viewer.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Access for all:[inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Access for all:[inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA012.|~|Poster shows a woman with her arm around a young girl, we presume they are mother and daughter. There is a ribbon behind the words which are above them.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: N'oublie pas le secret de Valery [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: N'oublie pas le secret de Valery [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional text: La santé, un droit pour tous! Meteor est un outil d'éveil aux valeurs humanitaires destiné aux enfants de 10 à 12 ans. En découvrant l'histoire vraie d'un enfant de leur âge, les écoliers prennent consciences d'autres réalités et d'autres modes de vie. Meteor se compose d'un film, d'une brochure et d'un dossier pédagogique.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE011.|~|Poster depicts the face of a girl, Valery, in one large square panel bordered on its left edge by three smaller square panels showing Valery in different scenes: the top panel shows her with classmates; the middle one shows her holding a flip board presentation on AIDS and STD's; and the bottom one shows her being embraced by a younger girl. A fourth circular panel in the upper right corner of the main panel shows an urban landscape, most likely Valery's hometown. The poster serves as an advertisement for Meteor, an educational kit that teaches children about other children affected by AIDS.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Translated additional poster text: Health, everyone's right! Meteor is a tool for fostering humane values, aimed at children 10 to 12 years old. By hearing stories from children their age, students become aware of other realities and other ways of life. Meteor consists of a film, a booklet, and teaching manual.
Alternate Title.translated: Don't forget Valery's secret

Item Title: Aktive fyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Stereotyping|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Aktive fyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.|~|Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Morten Wøldike; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK013.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|A young man in a green t-shirt and black jeans stands with one hand hitched in his pants pocket. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether gay men who are dominant (i.e. "tops") in sexual situations are less likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Active guys never have HIV -- or what?

Item Title: Villige fyre har altid HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Stereotyping|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Villige fyre har altid HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Queerstock; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS.|~|Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK012.|~|A shirtless young man in jeans and a baseball cap stands pointing at his buttocks. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether sexually promiscuous gay men are more likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Willing guys always have HIV – or what?

Item Title: Unge fyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]

Title: Unge fyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]

Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK015.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|A young man wearing a silver bracelet and necklace, and a black sleeveless top and pants. His hands are in the air as though he is dancing and snapping his fingers.  A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether young gay men are less likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK014.|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|A male with his back turned is pulling down his jeans to reveal his buttocks. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether gay men who play a more submissive role (i.e. "bottoms") in sexual situations are more likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Passive guys always have HIV -- or what?

Item Title: Grande simulatrice [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Grande simulatrice [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Les IST* ne sont pas toujours visibles. Faites un dépistage.*Infections sexuellement transmissible
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE012.|~|Translated additional poster text: Sexually transmitted diseases are not always visible. Track them down.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Poster depicts an unmade bed. Two pillows are partially shown: one is black and the other is black-and-white, with a pattern of circles encompassing radially-oriented swirls, reminiscent of the motion that induces hypnosis. A similarly patterned comforter is pulled back to reveal a white satin sheet with thin folds arranged in the shape of the word: Syphilis. The phrase "La Grande Simulatrice" is inscribed underneath in a red dot-matrix, suggestive of bullet holes.  Possibly encourages the user to have the stealth of a skilled hunter to track down and eliminate undetectable STDS--by practicing safe sex.
Alternate Title.translated: Grand illusionist

Item Title: Karrierefyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Karrierefyre har aldrig HIV – eller hvad? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Text in bottom left corner of poster: Design: Mikkel Sonne; Foto: Morten Wøldike; Tryk: Eks-Skolens Treykkeri APS.|~|Additional poster text: Farlige formodninger? De fleste mænd bruger kondom og glidecreme, når de har sex med en ny partner. Af og til bruger nogle mænd dog andre metoder til at undgå at blive smittet eller at smitte sex-partneren. Nogle prover at gætte sig frem til, om sex-partneren er hiv-smittet eller ej. Det kan være ved at se på hans alder, hvad han gor i sengen, eller hvor man mødte hinanden. Men hverken alder, mødestad eller seksuel erfaring kan fortælle, om en person er smittet med hiv eller ej.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item DK016.|~|Translated additional poster text: Dangerous conjectures? Most men use condoms and lubrication, when they have sex with a new partner. Every now and then some men use other methods to avoid being infected or infecting their sex partner. Some try to guess whether their sex partner is HIV-positive or not. It can be worth it to look at his age, what he does in bed, or how one met. But neither age, meeting place or sexual experience can tell whether a person is HIV-positive or not.|~|Organization web site: http://www.farligeformodninger.dk|~|A young man with a shaved head wearing a green polo shirt and standing with his arms crossed. A drawing of a heart with an arrow coming out of the top right (modeled on the male symbol?) appears in the top right corner as a logo for the STOP AIDS organization. Poster questions whether career-oriented me, or "yuppies," are less likely to be HIV-positive, and encourages viewers to avoid making assumptions.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Career guys never have HIV -- or what?

Item Title: People's faces and their prejudices toward people with HIV and AIDS [descriptive]
Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|World AIDS Day|~|Prejudice|~|AIDS phobia
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: People's faces and their prejudices toward people with HIV and AIDS [descriptive]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: "Blijf van mijn zuster."  "Wat gaat onze familie daar van zeggen?"  "Je verdient het."  "Blijf uit onze buurt."  "Je kan er niet bij in onze klas."  "Wij mogen niet met jou spelen."  "Prachtig cv, maar ben je seropositief?"  "Ga ergens anders slapen."  "He is je eigen schuld."  Dit zijn maar enkele van de meest pijnlijke gevolgen van HIV en AIDS.  Help ons mee te vechten tegen angst, schaamte, vooroordelen en onrechtvaardigheid, wereldwijd.  Doe mee, check www.sensoa.be.  1 december.  Wereldaidsdag.  Geef om AIDS.  096-555- 55 55-95.  Gebaseerd op een campagne van UNAIDS.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE010.|~|Translated additional poster text: "Stay away from my sister."  "What will our family say about that?"  "You deserve it."  "Stay out of our neighborhood."  "You can't be in our class."  "We should not play with you."  "Wonderful résumé, but are you HIV positive?"  "Go somewhere else to sleep."  "It is your own fault."  These are just some of the most painful consequences of HIV and AIDS.  Help us fight fear, shame, prejudice and injustice worldwide.  Get involved, check www.sensoa.be.  December 1.  World Aids Day.  Give to AIDS.  096-555- 55 55-95.  Based on a campaign of UNAIDS.|~|Nine disapproving faces of men, women, and children, accompanied by the judgemental and prejudical things about HIV and AIDS they are saying or thinking.

Item Title: Oraal, vaginaal, anaal.  En verbaal? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Oraal, vaginaal, anaal.  En verbaal? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Zeg beter meteen waar je je goed bij voelt.  Wat je verwacht, waar je grenzen liggen.  En vraag van je partner hetzelfde.  Want goeie afspraken maken goeie seks.  Sensoa.  Praat over seks.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE013.|~|A nude man and a woman appear to be having sexual intercourse on a couch.  There are black bars over their mouths, signifying that they are censoring themselves.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Translated additional poster text: Talk about what you feel good about right away. What you expected, your borders. And ask the same of your partner. Because good communication means good sex.  Sensoa.  Talk about sex.
Alternate Title.translated: Oral, vaginal, anal.  And verbal?

Item Title: Je tong verloren tijdens het kussen?  [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Je tong verloren tijdens het kussen?  [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Verliefd zijn op elkaar wil nog niet zeggen dat je elkaars gedachten kunt lezen.  Durf dus allebei te zeggen en te vragen waar je je goed bij voelt, wat je van elkaar verwacht en waar je grenzen liggen.  Want goede afspraken maken goede seks.Sensoa.  Praat over seks.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE015.|~|A male and a female lie naked together, posed to be near kissing.  There are black bars over their mouths, signifying that they are censoring themselves.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|Translated additional poster text: Just because you're attracted to each other doesnot mean that you can read each other's thoughts. So be bold enough to say and ask what you feel good about, what you expect from one another, and where your boundaries lie.  Because good communication means good sex.  Sensoa.  Talk about sex.
Alternate Title.translated: Lost your tongue during the kissing?

Item Title: Pijpen: gebruik je hoofd [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually transmitted diseases|~|Oral sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Pijpen: gebruik je hoofd [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1. Bij pijpen loop je makkelijk een soa op.  2. Er is ook een klein risico op HIV.  3. Wondjes in de mond verhogen de risico's.  4. Heb je een soa, dan loop je makkelijker hiv op.  Lees er meer over in de folder!  AIDS en soatelefoon 078 15.15.15, www.sensoa.be.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE042a.|~|Translated additional poster text: 1. When you give a blowjob, you can easily get an STD.  2. There is also a small risk of HIV.  3. Wounds in the mouth increase the risks.  4. If you have an STD, you are more likely to get HIV.  Read more about it in the folder!  AIDS and STD hotline: 078 15.15.15, www.sensoa.be.|~|A black and white closeup of a man's nose and mouth.  The poster text explains that it's possible to get HIV through oral sex, and very easy to contract an STD.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: To give a blowjob: use your head

Item Title: On pense que-- on croit que-- mais les suppositions ne nous protègent pas [inscribed].
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Unsafe sex|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Gay men--Communication
Personal or Corporate Name.funder: Terrence Higgins Trust|~|Communauté française de Belgique
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: On pense que-- on croit que-- mais les suppositions ne nous protègent pas [inscribed].
Description.inscription: First quotation adjacent to images: "Je suis séropositif, j'ai pensé qu'il l'était aussi. Il n'a pas proposé le préservatif."["I'm HIV positive, I thought that he was also. He didn't offer a condom."]|~|Second quotation adjacent to images: "Je pense que je suis séronégatif. Je présume qu'il l'est aussi puisqu'il n'utilize pas de préservatif. Si il avait le sida, il le dirait." ["I think I'm HIV negative. I assume that he is also since he doesn't use a condom. If he had AIDS, he would say so."]|~|Text at bottom of poster: Nous tenons à remercier The Terrence Higgins Trust et la Communauté française pour leur précieux soutien. Coordination: Thierry Martin. Ed. resp.: François Delor.|~|Additional text at bottom of poster: Pour obtenir notre brochure ... www.exaequo.be
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE028.|~|According to the publisher's website, viewed Jan. 31, 2008, the theme of this poster was the theme of a 1999 campaign.|~|Poster depicts two gay men dressed in orange and black clothing, standing apart and with their backs to each other, one looking over his shoulder at the other. The image is blurred,suggesting that they are not seeing each other clearly. Two quotations adjacent to the images indicate what each man is thinking, revealing that each has made false assumptions about the other.
Alternate Title.translated: We think that-- We believe that-- but assumptions don't protect us.

Description.inscription: Additional text at bottom of poster: Pour obtenir notre brochure ... www.exaequo.be|~|Text at bottom of poster: Nous tenons à remercier The Terrence Higgins Trust et la Communauté française pour leur précieux soutien. Coordination: Thierry Martin. Ed. resp.: François Delor.|~|Quotation above the image: "Hier, je n'ai pas mis de préservatif. Il m'a fait perdre la tête. Mais il n'était sûrement pas contaminé, il était jeune et paraissait vraiment en bonne santé." [Yesterday, I didn't use a condom. He made me lose my head. But he was definitely not infected, he was young and seemed really healthy.]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE030.|~|According to the publisher's website, viewed Jan. 31, 2008, the theme of this poster was the theme of a 1999 campaign.|~|Poster depicts two gay men, one dressed in an orange shirt and black trousers, the other in an open blue shirt and black trousers, standing apart and with their backs to each other. The image is blurred, possibly suggesting a lack of clear understanding or perception. A quotation above the image indicates that one man has made a potentially false assumption about the other and has engaged in unsafe sex.
Alternate Title.translated: We think that-- we believe that-- but assumptions don't protect us.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE024.|~|Poster depicts a shirtless young man in jeans standing sideways with his hands in his pockets. Tucked underneath the band of his jeans is the informational kit "In Ze Pocket." Information for how to get the kit is provided at the bottom of the poster.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE025.|~|Additional translated poster text: A total of nearly 100 pages of practical information and testimonies from people living with HIV. Item Title: Es gibt Dinge... die darf man nicht vergessen [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: HIV Infections--therapy|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Es gibt Dinge... die darf man nicht vergessen [inscribed]
Description.inscription: "AIDS ist ein großes, weltweit zunehmendes Problem. Es bleibt eine tödliche Krankheit, für die es in absehbarer Zukunft keine Schutzimpfung oder Heilung gibt. Medikamente können des Ausbruch von Aids nach einer HIV-Ansteckung nur verzögern." (AIDS is a large, world-wide increasing problem. It remains a fatal illness does not remain, for in the forseeable future there is no vaccinaton or cure. Medicines can only delay the onset of AIDS after an HIV infection)
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item GW246.|~|Part of the "Gib AIDS keine chance" campaign.  Image of a Dalmatian chained to a lightpost in the middle of a desert and sand dunes with the sand tinted red.|~|Poster number GW177 has the same image but different text.
Alternate Title.translated: There are things one should never forget

Item Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items CN033_1 and CN033_2 (back).|~|There is an additional inscription next to the four pictures of native Canadians:The Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network Inc. (CAAN) is a non-profit coalition of individuals and organizations which provides leadership, support, and advocacy for Aboriginal people affected and infected by HIV/AIDS regardless of where they reside. These four Aboriginal people in the photo to the left have all been affected by HIV/AIDS, fear and discrimination in some way, and come forward as a part of this year’s Aboriginal AIDS Awareness Day Poster Campaign to tell their stories. It is the goal of these individuals, and of all the members and associate members of the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network, to make sure that all Aboriginal people in Canada have the facts about HIV, both to protect ourselves and our families, and to help those of us already infected with the disease achieve the quality of life that we deserve. For more information on Aboriginal people and HIV/AIDS call the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network toll-free at 1-800-285-2226 or go to our webpage at WWW.caan.ca.|~|Eight men and women are standing or walking on the edge of a hill with black cloud in sky. One of the men wearing boots and pants with no shirt on, has his two hand around his mouth with a position of shouting.

Item Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items CN031_1 and CN031_2 (back).|~|There is a picture of a smiling man with shaved head on the bottom of the poster with additional inscription: My name is Duane Morrisseau-Beck. I am Métis, and am 34 years old. I was born to a French Canadian father and Ojibwa mother and raised in The Pas, Manitoba as an adoptee in a Ukrainian family. I am two-spirited, and I have HIV. This disease tests the endurance of your spirit. Knowing that my Métis identity in this country is at jeopardy everyday fuels me to continue fighting not only for my life, but the life and continuation of my people. The best way to face fear is to meet in head on, or not recognize that the word even exists. Wipe out fear and you have understanding. The term HIV/AIDS has created out of a virus so small, it has the world up in arms. The answer to dealing with this is not to be judgmental and share with your family the wonders of life and the uniqueness that makes it our world. For more information on Aboriginal people and HIV/AIDS call the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network toll-free at 1-800-285-2226 or go to our webpage at WWW.caan.ca.|~|An old Aboriginal man with long gray hair, wearing a white shirt and native made earring and necklaces, looking at distance with a worried and sad face. There are black clouds over a farm and stormy rain in the background.

Item Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items CN032_1 and CN032_2 (back).|~|An Aboriginal woman wearing a sleeveless shirt, tall collar covers her neck. She has long hair and looks concerned and unhappy. There is a farm and black cloud in sky and storm behind the farm in the background of her.|~|On the bottom of the poster is a picture of a smiling man with baseball hat and goatee beard and mustache, wearing a white t-shirt with inscription, Hockey …on it and sitting with a smiling baby next to additional inscription: My name is Jake Linklater. I am 32 years old and I am an Ojibway from the Cape Croker Band in Wiarton, Ontario. I worked at the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network in Ottawa for two years and the experience changed my life. My wife and I went home to the reserve and fought to have an HIV/AIDS curriculum put into our school so that our children could be educated about the disease. When I lived on the reserve, people with HIV/AIDS weren’t a big priority for me. When a woman within our community found out she was infected, the biggest thing we all thought was who was with her, who slept with who, and am I OK? That same woman didn’t get much help on our reserve, and I didn’t really care one way or the other about her. I believed if you were infected it was tour own fault – for choosing a different lifestyle, for not being married. Working with people with HIV/AIDS has opened us up to be more compassionate and understanding and hopefully we can change how people on our reserve think about HIV and those who live with this disease. For more information on Aboriginal People and HIV/AIDS call the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network toll-free at 1-800-285-2226 or go to our webpage at WWW.caan.ca.

Item Title: Si tout ce que vous savez de moi est que j'ai le VIH, vous ne me connaissez pas du tout [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si tout ce que vous savez de moi est que j'ai le VIH, vous ne me connaissez pas du tout [inscribed]
Description.inscription: La Semaine canadienne de sensibilisation au VIH/sida 2002, 24 novembre au 1er décembre 2002.|~|Additional poster text: Chaque année, le VIH infecte encore des milliers de Canadiens. Et nos attitudes affectent leur vie tous les jours. N'import quand. N'importe où. N'importe qui. Le VIH/sida n'a pas de préférence.|~|Les vues exprimées ici ne représente pas nécessairement la position officielle de Santé Canada.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN036_2.|~|A seated man wearing a white dress shirt with collar open and sleeves rolled up gazes openly and directly at the viewer. Indistinctly seen behind him is what appears to be a blackboard, possibly indicating that he is a white-collar worker. He is neither old nor young, and neither his ethnicity nor his occupation is apparent, hence he represents Everyman.
Alternate Title.translated: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me
Relation.hasVersion: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me [English]
Alternate Title.other: Semaine canadienne de sensibilisation au VIH/sida 2002
Alternate Title.inscribed: Moi aussi, j'ai des rêves et des espoirs

Item Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items CN035_1 and CN035_2 (back).|~|An happy old Aboriginal man, wearing a fare coat with the hood over a ski hat. Behind him is a scene of water and shore before mountains with black cloud in sky.|~|In bottom of poster a picture shows an smiling native Canadian woman with additional inscription:My name is Zipporah Ypma. I am an Inuk woman born in Main Labrador. I worked as a nursing assistant in Labrador for many years. I have two grown children born after a year-long stint in the Armed Forces. I spent a number of years in the Arctic communities of Clyde River and Yellowknife. When I came to Ottawa, I agreed to join the steering committee of the Canadian Inuit HIV/AIDS Network and add my voice to the growing number of Inuit working to prevent the spread of HIV and AIDS among our people. I do my best to encourage people to reach out with open hearts to those in need and help them to understand that this is just a disease. It does not change the true spirit of people living with HIV or AIDS. Discrimination is rooted in fear. Combating fear requires all of us to make sure others have the facts and that we remind them of the Inuit values and traditions of caring and concern for our community members in need. For more information on Aboriginal people and HIV/AIDS call the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network toll-free 1-800-285-2226 or go to our webpage at WWW.caan.ca.

Item Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV/AIDS. Fears. Discrimination. It can end with us [inscribed].
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items CN034_1 and CN034_2 (back).|~|An Aboriginal woman is carrying her baby on a native baby carrier which is hanging on her back and watching the baby over her shoulder. Behind her, some people are walking toward white houses next to a farm and before mountains.|~|Additional inscription next to a picture of a young man wearing a baseball hat:My name is Audla Eetoorooloopiag Geetah-Cyr. I am an Inuk born in Iqaluit. I am 15 years old, and I live in Ottawa with my two fathers. My mother died from AIDS when I was only four years old. Sometimes people, not just kids, said mean things about my mother or called me names. It made us sad, not angry. People’s fear of HIV and AIDS is what made my mother decide it would be safer for me to be adopted out of my family by my dads in the south. My mother loved me enough to made sure I would be safe when she died. I am really proud of the remarkable things she did to educate Inuit about HIN/AIDS even they didn’t want to listen. Now tell people when it comes to HIV/AIDS not to be silent. Talk from your heart and tell people how you feel. Help them understand that the fear they feel is because they do not have facts and that they need to get them, not just for themselves but for their friends and family too. For more information on Aboriginal people and HIV/AIDS call the Canadian Aboriginal AIDS Network tool-free at 1-800-285-2226 or go to our webpage at WWW.caan.ca.

December 2002]|~|Additional poster text: N’importe quand. N’importe où. N’importe qui. Le VIH/sida n’a pas de préférence. [No matter when. No matter where. No matter who. HIV/AIDS has no preference.]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN045_2.|~|Photograph of boy, casually dressed in a tee-shirt, a necklace, and jeans. Se fâche quand les gens disent que le VIH/sida n'est plus un grave problème. [Average student. Likes to have a good time... Gets angry when people say that HIV/AIDS is no longer a serious problem.]
Alternate Title.translated: Me, HIV? Impossible

Item Title: How could someone like me be HIV positive? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Canadian Strategy on HIV/AIDS (Association)|~|Canadian HIV/AIDS Clearinghouse
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: How could someone like me be HIV positive? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Average student.  Likes to have a good time.  Wishes he could talk to his older brother more often.  Spaghetti and meatballs is his favourite meal.  Wants to learn to play euchre.  Has seen every episode of "Star Treck: Next Generation" at least twice.  Wants to become a teacher.  Gets angry when he hears people say that HIV/AIDS isn't a big deal anymore.  Canadian HIV/AIDS Awareness Week 2002- November 24-December 1, 2002
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN045_1.|~|Young man in his teens or early twenties, of mixed race, looking at the viewer and smiling.

Item Title: HIV. It doesn't discriminate. Do You? [inscribed]
Subject.descriptiveTopic: HIV-positive persons--Conduct of life|~|HIV-positive persons--Services for
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV. It doesn't discriminate. Do You? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: We give our care and support to people who get cancer from smoking. Why should we blame people who have become infected with HIV? People with HIV/AIDS deserve the same acceptance and understanding as anyone else with a life threatening illness.  Concerned? Trade fears for facts. Call for a free borchure. 1-807-345-2526.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN053.|~|Poster  has large "HIV" in handwriting style typeface at top, and line below is in smaller regular print "It doesn't discriminate" and main body of text with phone number is below.  In the lower left hand corner is a symbol wih a butterfly, above a lower case "act" followed by a stylized backwards "c", and the words AIDS Committe of Thunder Bay.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN054.|~|In lower left hand corner of poster is a stylized logo, with a butterfly and "act" in lower case letters, with a reverse "c" after "act".  In a black border at the bottom of the poster are the words "AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay."|~|Additional poster text:  I am 46. I am divorced and sexually active. I am a social drinker. I've had a number of partners and sometimes I forget to use a condom when I have sex. Not only that, I like to experiment with some sex partners. So, I worry about getting AIDS. I wish I had someone to talk to about this.  You do. Call (807)345-1516 or 1 800 488-5840 today.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Si tout ce que vous savez de moi est que j'ai le VIH, vous ne me connaissez pas du tout [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Moi aussi, j'ai des rêves et des espoirs. Chaque année, le VIH infecte encore des milliers de Canadiens. Et nos attitudes affectent leur vie tous le jours. = I have hopes and dreams just like you.  Thousands of Canadians are still being infected with HIV every year.  And they're being affected by our attitudes every day.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN051_2.|~|Also issued in an English version, with title: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me.|~|Poster depicts a young woman with folded, tattooed arms staring at the viewer.
Relation.derivedFrom: English: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me.

Item Title: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me. [inscribed]

Title: If all you know about me is that I have HIV, then you don't know anything about me. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Thousands of Canadians are still being infected with HIV every year.  And they're being affected by our attitudes every day.     Anytime.  Anywhere.  Anyone.  HIV/AIDS does not discriminate.     Canadian HIV?AIDS Awareness Week 2002- November 24-December 1, 2002.

Item Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|AIDS (Disease) in adolescence|~|Sex
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN055.|~|In the lower left hand corner of poster is a stylized logo, with a butterfly and "act" in lower case letters, with a reverse "c" after "act."  In a black border at the bottom of the poster are the words "AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.|~|Additional poster text:  "I am 15. I am sexually active. I don't like using condoms when I have sex.  Now I worry about getting AIDS.  I think I'm okay beacuse I have a steady boyfriend.  But I think he cheats on me sometimes.  I wish I had someone to talk to.  You do.  Call (807) 345-1516 or 1-800-488-5840 today."|~|Poster shows the eyes and part of forehead and nose of a young female.  It is a white backgorund, and the face is in color.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Are you negative about positives? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Are you negative about positives? [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN060.|~|The poster shows a picture featuring 9 people who (supposedly) are HIV positive.  All are smiling and looking happy.  Below the portrait are the words:  "Be Real. Respect. Protect. Each other. Next time you have sex, think about the thungs going on in your head-and his. Your life's important-so is his. ru4real.ca"|~|At the bottom of the poster are logo for numerous HIV and AIDS organizations in the Toronto area.  There is text that reads: "For more information, contact you local AIDS service organization."  The logos are for- 1. ACT-AIDS Committee of Toronto 416.340.4300 actotonto.org  2. ACAS-Asian Community AIDS Services 416.963-4300 acas.org  3. ASAAP-Alliance for South Asian AIDS Prevention 416.599.2727  4. Black C.A.P 416.977.9955 black-cap.com  5. Centro Para Gente de Habla Espana Centre for Spanish SPeaking Peoples 416.925.2800  spanishservices.org|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.other: Reality check : many of us are living with HIV. We're part of the community. We work and play together. We have sex.

Item Title: Whatever you call it, thanks for playing it safe [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Whatever you call it, thanks for playing it safe [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN058.|~|There is a logo in the lower right hand of poster with words "AIDS Vanvouver."|~|Poster is a reddish brown background with many lines of small print, containing gay and male sexual terms, many in slang.  At the bottom of the poster is the line "Whatever you call it, thanks for playing it safe.  GayMenPlaySafe.com"|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: What's going on in his head-and yours? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: What's going on in his head-and yours? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: The poster shows 9 people, smiling who are (supposedly) HIV positive.  Beneath the picture is the text:The poster shows a picture featuring 9 people who (supposedly) are HIV positive.  All are smiling and looking happy.  Below the portrait are the words:  "Be Real. Respect. Protect. Each other. Next time you have sex, think about the thungs going on in your head-and his. Your life's important-so is his. ru4real.ca"
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN063.|~|At the bottom of the poster are logo for numerous HIV and AIDS organizations in the Toronto area.  There is text that reads: "For more information, contact you local AIDS service organization."  The logos are for- 1. ACT-AIDS Committee of Toronto 416.340.4300 actotonto.org  2. ACAS-Asian Community AIDS Services 416.963-4300 acas.org  3. ASAAP-Alliance for South Asian AIDS Prevention 416.599.2727  4. Black C.A.P 416.977.9955 black-cap.com  5. Centro Para Gente de Habla Espana Centre for Spanish SPeaking Peoples 416.925.2800  spanishservices.org|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.other: Reality check : sometimes we feel that we dom't quite fit in-not hot eonogh, too old, not a "real" man.  We're part of the community, but we're also left out.

Item Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN056.|~|Additional poster text:  I am 23. I got into body building a few years ago.  A couple of friends and I started shooting steroids to bulk up more quickly.  Now, I sometimes shoot up at parties to get high. But I'm starting to worry about getting AIDS.  I wish there was someone I could talk to.  You do. Call (807) 345-1516 or 1-800-488-5840 today.|~|In the lower left hand corner of poster is a stylized logo, with a butterfly and "act" in lower case letters, with a reverse "c" after "act."  In a black border at the bottom of the poster are the words "AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.|~|Poster shows the eyes and part of forehead and nose of a young male.  It is a white backgorund, and the face is in color.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Whatever you call it, thanks for keeping it safe. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Whatever you call it, thanks for keeping it safe. [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN059.|~|Poster is a reddish brown background with 9 pictures of male mid-sections in sexually provocative situations.  Each picture has a caption uder it. "Butt Pirate. Ass Master.  Chicken Baster.  Pepito. Mary Maker. Jack Hammer. Long Dong Silver. The Big Baguette. Old One Eye."|~|At bottom of poster are the words: "Whatever you call it, thanks for keeping it safe."|~|There is a logo in the lower right hand corner of poster that says: "GayMenPlaySafe.com"|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Ce n'est pas le VIH qui m'isole, c'est vous! [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: MTV Networks|~|Canadian AIDS Society|~|Canada. Health Canada
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ce n'est pas le VIH qui m'isole, c'est vous! [inscribed]
Description.inscription: www.etvous.cpha.ca|~|Quand mes proches ont appris que j'avais le VIH, personne ne voulait plus rien partager avec moi... même pas la salle de bain,
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN065_2.|~|A young Black female standing alone staring into the distance and some other young adults talking together in the background.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: It's not HIV that isolates me, it's you!
Relation.hasVersion: It's not HIV that isolates me, it's you! (English)

Item Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: I am the changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN057.|~|"I am 28.  I do drugs.  My ex-boyfriend fixed me the first time.  So I never shoot up alone.  Sometimes I share my needles with my guys, and later I forget to make them use condoms.  But now I'm starting to worry about getting AIDS.  I wish there was someone who could help without preaching to me.  You do.  Call (807)345-1516 or 1-800-488-5840 today.|~|Poster is white and shows the eyes, part of forehead and nose of a female.  The face is in color.|~|In lower left hand corner of poster is a stylized logo, with a butterfly and "act" in lower case letters, with a reverse "c" after "act."  In a black border at the bottom are the words "AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay."|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Il aime ça sans capote. Il doit être séropositif [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|HIV-positive persons--Sexual behavior|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission|~|HIV Infections--transmission|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control|~|Gay men--Communication
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Il aime ça sans capote. Il doit être séropositif [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN071.|~|Other people involved in poster creation: Raúl Cabra, Andy Williams, Wesley Ito, Liz Craig and Jillian Moffett.|~|This poster depicts a grainy black and white photograph of a young white man with his head and chest visible, lying face-up on his back with his head on a pillow.  His eyes are shut and his brow is furrowed, lips are slightly open, suggesting that he is in the act of intercourse.  The text of the poster suggests the importance of not making assumptions, and of knowing about the other person’s HIV status to prevent contracting it.|~|Based on the San Francisco "Assumptions" campaign, the slogan reads, "Comment fais-tu pour savoir?" English version is: "How do you know what you know?" www.penses-y.ca|~|Poster is copyright 2004 Cabra Diseño and San Francisco AIDS Foundation. www.cabradiseno.com
Alternate Title.translated: He does it raw. He must be positive.
Relation.hasVersion: He does it raw. He must be positive. [English]

Item Title: Il me l'aurait dit s'il était séropositif.  Il me l'aurait dit s'il était séronégatif [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|HIV-positive persons--Sexual behavior|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Transmission|~|HIV Infections--transmission|~|Gay men--Sexual behavior|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control|~|Gay men--Communication
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Il me l'aurait dit s'il était séropositif.  Il me l'aurait dit s'il était séronégatif [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN076.|~|Based on the San Francisco "Assumptions" campaign, the slogan reads, "Comment fais-tu pour savoir?" English version is: "How do you know what you know?" www.penses-y.ca|~|Poster is copyright 2004 Cabra Diseño and San Francisco AIDS Foundation. www.cabradiseno.com|~|A poster with two black-and-white photos placed side-by side, showing the upper bodies of two men, one behind the other, both facing to the left of the scene.  The man on the left is light complected, with short dark hair, mustache and beard, and his eyes are closed.  The second man is posed behind the first; he has dark skin and his eyes are also closed. The positions suggest that they have just had anal intercourse. Each man is making an assumption about the other and whether each is HIV-positive or negative. Poster text suggests the importance of being informed about HIV to prevent contracting it.|~|Other people involved in poster creation: Raúl Cabra, Andy Williams, Wesley Ito, Liz Craig and Jillian Moffett.
Alternate Title.translated: He'd tell me if he's positive. He'd tell me if he's negative.

Item Title: 4,200*; *Number of Canadians infected with HIV each year [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: 4,200*; *Number of Canadians infected with HIV each year [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: $720 million; Annual cost of these new infections to our health care system.; 11; Number of years federal HIV/AIDS funding has been frozen.; 0; Time, in years, to waste.; HIV can be prevented, but not cured.  1993 funding levels are no longer mobilizing effective prevention, treatment or research.  Contact Prime Minister Paul Martin today to voice your outrage.; www.cdnaids.ca.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN068.|~|Poster shows various HIV stats in relation to Canada.  Poster encourages people to support funding for HIV/AIDS research because the amount of money used is minimal.

Item Title: Je suis venu en lui. Il doit être séropositif. Il est venu en moi. Il doit être séronégatif [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--transmission|~|HIV-positive persons--Sexual behavior|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|HIV Infections--transmission|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control|~|Gay men--Communication
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Je suis venu en lui. Il doit être séropositif. Il est venu en moi. Il doit être séronégatif [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN078.|~|Other people involved in poster creation: Raúl Cabra, Andy Williams, Wesley Ito, Liz Craig and Jillian Moffett.|~|The poster depicts a grainy black and white photograph of two men, one lying face down and the other lying face down on top of him; only the heads and shoulders can be seen. Both men have their eyes closed, and their positions suggest that they are having anal intercourse. Each man is making an assumption about the other and whether he is HIV-positive or negative. Poster text suggests the importance of being informed about HIV to prevent contracting it.|~|Based on the San Francisco "Assumptions" campaign, the slogan reads, "Comment fais-tu pour savoir?" English version is: "How do you know what you know?" www.penses-y.ca|~|Poster is copyright 2004 Cabra Diseño and San Francisco AIDS Foundation.
Alternate Title.translated: I came inside him. He must be positive. He came inside me. He must be negative
Relation.hasVersion: I came inside him.  He must be positive.  He came inside me.  He must be negative. [English]

His left elbow is on the left leg of his passenger. Passenger is a young Asian man wearing a black studded leather vest over a black sleeveless shirt and jeans and wearing a white head bandana with a red spot and Asian inscription on it. His right is arm on the driver’s shoulder and his left hand in his jean’s back-pocket. Many lights in the windows of several high-rises behind show a bright night view behind them. Poster promotes safe sex through condom use.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN027.|~|Translated additional poster text: AIDS is growing in our community. It's time to act! For more information about the Council or the strategy concerning HIV/AIDS in the African and Caribbean communities in Ontario, please call ACCHO.|~|Twenty individual people of color are posed standing in a line that is the shape of an AIDS ribbon. There are men, women and children, representing African and Caribbean people and families from all walks of life, and wearing clothing that is primarily orange in color. They are being urged to become active and learn more about AIDS in their community.

Item Title: Getting high n' hot. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Information services|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Getting high n' hot. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: www.actoronto.org|~|The AIDS Commitee of Toronto [ACT] is a community-based charitable organization that provides support, HIV prevention and education services for people living and at risk for HIV/AIDS.|~|Know the choices! Don't share your works. Cleaning needles/syringes with bleach and water can kill HIV but not get rid of Hep C. Plan ahead before getting drunk or high.|~|Know your risks! Sharing needles/syringes is an easy way to get or pass on HIV and Hepatitis C. Getting high or drunk with peopole you don't know increases your risk for sexual assault which can put you at risk for HIV infections.|~|Produced by the Women's Community Development Program. AIDS Comitee of Toronto.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Item Title: Women lovin' women [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Information services|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Women lovin' women [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Know your choices! Avoid sharing sex toys (including vibrators) or else, use latex condoms. Use a latex barrier like a dental dam or un-lubricated condom (cut lengthwise) fpr oral sex.|~|The AIDS Commitee of Toronto [ACT] is a community-based charitable organization that provides support, HIV prevention and education services for people living and at risk for HIV/AIDS.|~|Produced by the Women's Community Development Program. AIDS Comitee of Toronto.|~|www.actoronto.org|~|Know your risks! Our risk for sexually transmitted infections [STIs] - including HIV/AIDS - has everything to do with what we do, not who we are. There have been reported cases of HIV transmission between women.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN081.|~|Image of a naked woman shown in the poster. Her hand is visible, wearing a glove and holding a sex toy with a condom on it.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: VIH/SIDA. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: VIH/SIDA. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Il peut se retirer, mais le VIH demeurera a jamais. Si tu contractes le VIH, tu en seras atteinte pour la vie. C'est possible de l'éviter. Sois consciente des risques- sois consciente de tes choix. [He can pull out but HIV never will. Once you get HIV, it never goes away. It can be avoided. Know your risks-know your choices.]|~|In the poster there is the website of the Canadian AIDS society: www.cdnaids.ca/risques/choix. At the bottom of the poster it says: La société Canadienne du sida remercie les membres du Comité consultatif national des jeunes de 2004 pour leurs précieuses contributions  au développement de cette campagne.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library.
