Item Title: True leaders. HIV AIDS the healing begins with us. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: True leaders. HIV AIDS the healing begins with us. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: In the bottom of the poster there is a red ribbon and this note in both languages English and French: Aboriginal AIDS Awareness Day, December 1. Journee de Sensibilisation des Autochtones sur le Sida, 01 Decembre.Also there is the website of CAAN which is:www.caan.ca
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN024_1.|~|Against a background of rolling green hills and a river, native Canadians are depicted interacting with each other. In the foreground, an older woman is shown cooking for a group surrounding her. To her left is a young man wearing graduation robes and holding a feather. Behind them, two women are talking; one is holding a clipboard and wearing an AIDS ribbon. To the right, a young boy is being handed a bowl by a kneeling older man. The poster suggests that native people can and should take a leadership role in prevention the spread of HIV/AIDS and providing support for those already infected.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Les vrais chefs. VIH SIDA la guerison commence avec nous.

Item Title: HIV/AIDS.  He can pull out but HIV never will [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV/AIDS.  He can pull out but HIV never will [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Once you get HIV, it never goes away. It can be avoided. Know your risks-know your choices.|~|In the poster there is the website of the Canadian AIDS society: www.cdnaids.ca/risks/choicesIn the bottom of the poster it says: The Canadian AIDS Society would like to thank the 2004 National Youth Advisory Committee for their valuable input in developing this campaign.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN020_1.|~|A man and woman are shown embracing, against a green and black background suggesting the outdoors. Heart shapes surround them.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Relation.hasVersion: French [VIH/SIDA Il peut se retirer, mais le VIH demeurera a jamais]

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN025_1.|~|At the bottom of the poster, there is a red AIDS ribbon and the text December 1, Nunakakaakhimaut AIDSNI Naluhuiktailiktakhait Ubla [Tiisiivva 1, Nunaqaqkaaqsimajut Aukut Tusaumanirmut Ullunggat].|~|A colorful graphic illustration of people, with a background suggesting clouds and snowy mountains. One man is playing a fiddle while another looks on, and there are music notes next to them. The graphic illustrates the textual message that there is hope for more supportive communities and hope that together, HIV/AIDS can be overcome.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Angayukaatiavut. HIV AIDS, anianailigutit piniaktut uvaptinit [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN024_2.|~|Against a background of rolling green hills and a river, native Canadians are depicted interacting with each other. In the foreground, an older woman is shown cooking for a group surrounding her. To her left is a young man wearing graduation robes and holding a feather. Behind them, two women are talking; one is holding a clipboard and wearing an AIDS ribbon. To the right, a young boy is being handed a bowl by a kneeling older man. The poster suggests that native people can and should take a leadership role in prevention the spread of HIV/AIDS and providing support for those already infected.|~|At the bottom of the poster, there is a red AIDS ribbon and the text December 1, Nunakakaakhimaut AIDSNI Naluhuiktailiktakhait Ubla [Tiisiivva 1, Nunaqaqkaaqsimajut Aukut Tusaumanirmut Ullunggat].|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Hope: HIV/AIDS, the healing begins with us [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Optimism|~|AIDS (Disease)|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|HIV-positive persons--Conduct of life|~|HIV infections
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hope: HIV/AIDS, the healing begins with us [inscribed]
Description.inscription: www.caan.ca  1-888-285-2226|~|Additional poster text: Hope for a cure. Hope that together -- HIV/AIDS can be overcome. Hope for a better tomorrow by living a better today. Hope for more supportive communitites. Hope that our people will once again thrive. Faith in the traditional strenths of our people. HIV/AIDS. The healing begins with us.December 1, Aboriginal AIDS Awareness Day.|~|Additional poster text: L'espoire d'une cure. L'espoire qu'ensemble -- le VIH/SIDA peut être surmonté. L'espoire d'un avenir meilleur en vivant mieux aujourd'hui. L'espoir de communautés plus coopératives. L'espoire que notre peuple réussira encore une fois. La foi dans les forces traditionnelles de notre peuple. VIH/SIDA. La guérison commence avec nous. 01 decembre, Journée de sensibilisation des autochtones sur le SIDA.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN025_2.|~|A colorful graphic illustration of people, with a background suggesting clouds and snowy mountains.  One man is playing a fiddle while another looks on, and there are music notes next to them. Another man (wearing an AIDS ribbon) is adjusting the neckerchief of a man in traditional native American dress. There is a mother (perhaps an Inuit woman, suggested by her clothing) with a child on her back. Finally, there are a man and woman holding hands. The graphic illustrates the textual message that there is hope for more supportive communities and hope that together, HIV/AIDS can be overcome.
Alternate Title.inscribed: Espoire: VIH/SIDA, la guérison commence avec nous

Item Title: Bravo. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: HIV-positive persons|~|Discrimination|~|Health Knowledge, Attitudes, Practice|~|Social isolation
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Sida Info Service (France)|~|France. Ministère des affaires sociales et de la solidarité nationale
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Bravo. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional text in French: "Le Ministére la santé et solidarités et L'inpes Luttent Contre la Discrimination des Personnes Séropositives."Translation in English: "Minister of Health and in solidarity with fight against the discrimination of the Persons who have tested positive with AIDS.”
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR084.|~|This poster is depicting a young girl with a long blond hair who is looking compassionately to the onlookers, as she is saying don’t worry you are not alone.  The inscription “Bravo, vous faites désormais partie des gens qui n'ont pas peur d'approcher une personne séropositive.” (Congratulations, you are here as part of a group of people who are not afraid to approach a person who has tested HIV positive,) is on the mouth of this young girl.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Congratulations.

Item Title: Party animal? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Party animal? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: AIDS loves a good party. A few drinks and every-one lets down their guard. Party smart. Keep one guard on duty. Use a condom.|~|For information call: 345-1516. ACT: A message from the AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN008.|~|The poster shows a picture of stuff leftover from a party like: a spoon, hypodermic needles, condoms, bottlecaps, a cup, pop corn and a piece of pizza. Next to the title there is also a picture of a condom as an essential guard during a party.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Bravo, vous faites désormais partie des gens qui n'ont pas peur d'approcher une personne séropositive. [inscribed]

Title: Bravo, vous faites désormais partie des gens qui n'ont pas peur d'approcher une personne séropositive. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional text in French. "Le Ministére la santé et solidarités et L'inpes Luttent Contre la Discrimination des Personnes Séropositives."Translation in English. "Minister of Health and in solidarity with fight against the discrimination of the Persons who have tested positive with AIDS.”
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR083.|~|The poster is depicting a young man with some beard and short hair who is looking straight to the onlooker. An inscription is placed right below his left eye. On the bottom of the poster there is an inscription about the sponsors and where to find information.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Congratulations, you are here as part of a group of people who are not afraid to approach a person who has tested HIV positive.

Item Title: We talk [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: We talk [inscribed]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK053.|~|Additional poster text: --We talked about everything. I hoped that meant we'd never have to talk about whether one of us might have HIV. It's taken time, but we're talking again. That's a start. But I wish we had talked about it before.|~|In white border at bottom of poster:  "For more information."  A logo in red for GlaxoSmithKline Positive Action at Work. And a second logo for NAT with a red ribbon National AIDS Trust.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Thank you. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Thank you. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text:  We want to say "Thank you" to all our HIV and AIDS Peer Educators.  Without them we wouldn't have been able to bring our employees all the information and workplace activities that help us fight HIV discrimination, prevent infections and promote testing, care and treatment.  It's not an easy job, but if you would like to join them, they still need more help.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK054.|~|The poster is a thank you note that expresses the feelings of the people who are getting the word out to people in the workplaces.  The word "Thank" is in light blue; the word "you" is in yellow.  The background of the poster is in a light red.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Changez le monde [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Changez le monde [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text:La discrimination liée au vih empêche les gens d'obtenir l'information et le soutien dont ils ont besoin. www.campaign.CPHA.ca. Le vih ne fait pas de discrimination.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN085_2.|~|Part of "Change the world" campaign.
Alternate Title.other: Defendez les droits humains.|~|Ensemble nous pouvons faire une différence.

Item Title: Changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Changing face of AIDS [inscribed]
Description.inscription: For information call: 1-807-345-1516. ACT: AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.|~|Additional poster text: BIGOT? HIV/AIDS does not discriminate between straight, gay, young, old, or the colour of one's skin. It sees us all equally- as potential targets. Get the facts. Risk? HIV/AIDS is a risk- especially if you drink before sex or use intravenous drugs. AIDS can be prevented. Learn how to protect yourself. GET IT? don't HIV/AIDS is final. And it's occuring more in women, our young people and aboriginal population. Find out what you can do about it. GOT IT? Living with HIV/AIDS isn't easy. Fear is terrible thing to face alone. If you or someone you know is infected, help is available. Give us a call.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN015.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|The poster doesn't have any picture, it only includes the word AIDS in big and in vertical way. On the letter A of AIDS it is written "The changing face of". Under the word AIDS there are 4 columns in each one there is a small text.

Item Title: Discriminación, si no te sube la presión, hazte un chequeo. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Discriminación, si no te sube la presión, hazte un chequeo. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: "Todo paciente tiene derecho a la mejor atencion de salud disponible, independientemente de su condicion de salud, raza, edad, orientacion sexual o nivel socioeconomico."|~|Additional poster text: "La discriminacion es un problema que afecta a toda la sociedad. En los servicios de salud, personas con VIH y otras enfermedades a menudo sufren discriminacion. Por eso, chequee los siguientes sintomas de discriminacion:  Rechazo a ingresar a pacientes con VIH/SIDA en un establecimiento de salud, retrasar la atencion del paciente, demora o negacion de otras formas de atencion como higiene o alimentacion, alta prematura de pacientes, realizacion de pruebas medicas sin consentimiento del paciente, violacion de la confidencialidad dentro o fuera del sistema de salud, comentarios impropios como el uso de ironias o juicios fuera de lugar, excesivas medidas de precaucion al asistirlos.  Trabajadores de la salud: aliados en la lucha contra la discriminacion.|~|Translated additional poster text:  "Every patient has the right to the best available health care, regardless of your health condition, race, age, sexual orientation or socioeconomic status."|~|Translated additional poster text: Discrimination is a problem that affects all society. Within the health services, people with HIV and other diseases are sometimes affected by discrimination. Check for these symptoms of discrimination: Refusal to admit patients to health care facility, delay treatment, other forms of care (e.g. food hygiene) delay or withheld, premature discharge of patients, testing with consent, breach of confidentiality within or outside the health care system, inappropriate comments or behavior (e.g. shouting, rudeness), use of excessive precautions. [Health workers: partners in the fight against discrimination]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA008.|~|The web site for the Pan American Health Organization appears on the blood pressure machine: http://www.paho.org/|~|Poster depicts a blood pressure machine at the center of the poster and the word "discriminacion" (discrimination) all across the poster.
Alternate Title.translated: Discrimination, if your reaction is slow, get a checkup.

Item Title: Вы меня услышали сегодня? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Women--Health and welfare|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Women's rights
Personal or Corporate Name.sponsor: Global Coalition on Women and AIDS|~|World AIDS Campaign
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Вы меня услышали сегодня? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Нет уважения-нет надежды. Многие из нас не имеют достаточных прав и уважения в своей общине. Мы чаще подвергаемся сексуальному насилию и нам труднее найти работу или владеть собственностью. Это делает нас более уязвимыми к ВИЧ. Это надо менять. Равенство для женщин помогает бороться со СПИДом. [Net uvazhenii︠a︡-net nadezhdy. Mnogie iz nas ne imei︠u︡t dostatochnykh prav i uvazhenii︠a︡ v svoeĭ obshchine. My chashche podvergaemsi︠a︡ seksualʹnomu nasilii︠u︡ i nam trudnee naĭti rabotu ili vladetʹ sobstvennostʹi︠u︡. Ėto delaet nas bolee ui︠a︡zvimymi k VICh. Ėto nado meni︠a︡tʹ. Ravenstvo dli︠a︡ zhenshchin pomogaet borotʹsi︠a︡ so SPIDom].
Description.note: Photograph of a woman, probably of South Asian descent, looking towards but not directly at the viewer.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UNA016.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Title: Discriminación. Si no la ves, hazte un chequeo [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Trabajadores de salud: aliados en la lucha contra la discriminación. Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Item Title: Take one off: Put one on. [inscribed]

Title: Take one off: Put one on. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: When you want to take it all off, play it cool. Make a condom part of your lovemaking. Avoid making AIDS your lifelong partner. TAKE CARE. USE A CONDOM.|~|For information call: 345-1516. ACT: A message from the AIDS Committee of Thunder Bay.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN012.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.|~|The poster shows a picture of a woman's underwear and a used condom, also a picture of a condom next to the title.

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item CN010.|~|The poster shows a picture of a female hand giving a condom to a male hand, this man is handling in his other hand an alcoholic beverage.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Description.note: At bottom right of poster: logo of ARCAT, with its internet address: www.arcat-sida.org|~|Published in 2000.|~|Poster depicts a clean-cut man wearing a suit and standing at the front of a crowded elevator car filled with what appear to be other business-suited people. Item Title: Sida, le seul moyen de savoir, c'est de faire le test. [inscribed]

Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR085.|~|A black man is looking at a mirror. His back is partially seen and his profile can be seen from his back in front of the mirror. His reflection in the mirror depicts his right arm’s fingers on his face. He seems that he is worried or wondering if he is infected.  He is presumably in a bathroom, as there are two toothbrushes and a razor in a cup and a whitening powder case on the shelf just below the mirror.  A statement below the poster informs “Le test de dépostage est anonyme, confidentiel et gratuit. Appelez gratuitement Sida Info Service au 080840800. www.sida-info-service.org"|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS, the only way of knowing is to take the test.

Item Title: Sexually transmitted infections [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Self-care, Health|~|Birth control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sexually transmitted infections [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: There are many different STIs-and some you would not know you have without a check up. Using condoms protects against many common STIs as well as unwanted pregnancies and HIV. Leaving an STIs untreated can turn a simple problem into a serious one, and may leave you more vulnerable to HIV infection. Have a check up, for the sake of your sexual health.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK033.|~|Poster depicts image of stethoscope with a condom in place of a diaphragm.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Discrimination, if your reaction is slow, get a checkup [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Discrimination|~|Health care personnel
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Discrimination, if your reaction is slow, get a checkup [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text:  Every patient has the right to the best available health care, regardless of health condition, race, age, sexual orientation or socioeconomic status.|~|Additional poster text:  Discrimination is a problem that affects all society.  Within the health services, people with HIV and other diseases are sometimes affected by discrimination.  Check for these symptoms of discrimination: Refusal to admit patients to health care facility, delay treatment, other forms of care (e.g. food hygiene) delay or withheld, premature discharge of patients, testing with consent, breach of confidentiality within or outside the health care system, inappropriate comments or behavior (e.g. shouting, rudeness), use of excessive precautions. [Health workers:  partners in the fight against discrimination]
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. Under the word discrimination, there is a reflex hammer with several red ribbons attached to the side of the head of the hammer.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: HIV and AIDS: the facts [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Safe sex in AIDS prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|AIDS (Disease)--Risk factors|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: HIV and AIDS: the facts [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. It attacks the human immune system, leaving an infected person vulnerable to a number of serious illnesses and cancers. The virus lives in the blood, vaginal fluid and semen of infected people. But the virus does not survive for long in the open air and can only be passed on by certain kinds of direct contact.HIV is contracted through vaginal or anal sex without a condom, injection or injury with used needles, mother to unborn or newborn baby. HIV is not contracted through working with people with HIV or AIDS, coughs and sneezes, holding hands, insect bites, food or knives and forks, toilets or sinks, protected sex with proper use of a condom.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK031.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Making sense of global change [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: HIV-positive women|~|HIV-positive persons--Conduct of life|~|Discrimination|~|AIDS (Disease)--Patients--Family relationships|~|HIV Infections--transmission|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--Personal Narratives
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Making sense of global change [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: "When I got the news that I was HIV positive I didn't panic because I was not the first and I knew I wouldn't die immediately. But then I told my family. They stopped coming to see me and wouldn't even talk to me... but I persevered. I used to pester my younger sister to do my hair - she did my hair in the photograph and I thing it's why the man I'm with now was interested in me." Micah, Kabuta village, Zambia.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, items UK029_1 and UK029_2 (back).|~|Back side of poster contains 5 photographs and additional background text about Micah and other Panos programs, and solicits donations for Panos.|~|Front of poster depicts color photograph of an African woman with intricate braiding.|~|Date on back of poster, 2006, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Not until you're diagnosed HIV positive do you discover how sick people can get. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Not until you're diagnosed HIV positive do you discover how sick people can get. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Hate mail. Abusive phone calls. Even aggressive confrontations and physical attacks. This is how some people who are HIV positive are treated. And not just by strangers. By work colleagues, by former friends and sometimes even by close family. And it's not unheard of either for people with HIV to be discriminated against by health workers. Yet the fact is, there's no reason for them to be treated differently from anyone else. You can't contract HIV by working or socialising with someone who has it. And thanks to new treatments, its possible for people with HIV to lead full and active lives. All that's stopping them is other people's ignorance. Are you HIV prejudiced? To learn the facts, go to www.areyouhivprejudiced.org. By ending ignorance, we'll end prejudice.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK040.|~|Poster depicts HIV case study list, and is in black and white.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Do you have time? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Do you have time? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: five people worldwide die of AIDS every minute. Take a minute: 1st December is World AIDS Day. For confidential information and advice on safer sex, HIV and AIDS call 0800 567 123 anytime.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK036.|~|Poster depicts image of stopwatch.|~|Date on back of poster, 2004, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.

Item Title: Could you look me in the eye if you knew that I had HIV? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Could you look me in the eye if you knew that I had HIV? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: A lot of people couldn't. Some even go out of their way to avoid you. Even friends and members of your own family. Can you imagine how that feels? The isolation and the loneliness? Yet the fact is you can't contract HIV from working or socialising with someone who has is. And thanks to new treatments, most people with HIV can now lead full active lives. All that's stopping them is other people's ignorance. Are you HIV prejudiced? By ending ignorance, we'll end prejudice.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item UK038.|~|Poster depicts black and white photograph of man’s face. The question: “Could you look me in the eye if you knew that I had HIV?” is written in his eyes.

Item Title: Protégez-vous [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Protégez-vous [inscribed]
Description.inscription: On upper left side of poster: "Photo: Laurence & Renaud"
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR135.|~|Poster depicts three sides of a die, with names of men ("LUCAS", "SACHA") on two of the sides, and "SIDA" [AIDS] on the third side. According to the publisher's website, the die is meant to suggest that failure to use protection during sex is to gamble with one's life. The three sides of the die are intended to raise the question "With whom did you spend the night?" And to suggest that one of the answers could be: "AIDS".|~|Logo of the AIDES organization in lower right corner of poster.|~|Poster formed part of a 2004 campaign (information from publisher's website).|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Protect yourself

Item Title: Pour que l'espoir vous succède-- la solidarité en héritage [inscribed]

Description.inscription: Text on right-hand side of poster: AIDES 0404-- Maquette: S. Blot -- Illustration: PIEM extraite de "Petits enfants, Grands parents", edité par le Cherche midi.|~|Additional poster text: Léguer un bien ou faire un donation, c'est transmettre de l'espoir aux personnes touchées au-delà de sa propre vie. En tant qu'Association Reconnue d'Utilité Publique, AIDES peut recevoir des donations et des legs exonérés de tous droits de succession. L'integralité des biens légués est donc consacrée à la lutte contre le sida.
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR134.|~|Translation of additional poster text: To give to charity is to give hope to people we will never know. As an "Association Reconnue d'Utilité Publique", AIDES may receive donations and bequests exempt from inheritance taxes. The entirety of bequests can therefore be devoted to the fight against AIDS.|~|Poster consists of a drawing of an older man, wearing glasses, seated on a park bench with his arm around a child; the older man is pointing at the sky in which scattered stars and stars formed in the shapes of two hearts are present. Both the older man and the child are smiling and looking at the hearts in the sky.|~|Possibly part of a 2003-2004? campaign to encourage bequests and gifts to the Aides organization.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: So that hope will live on-- show you care by leaving something to charity

Description.inscription: Additional text in French:“Vous avez pris un risqué n’attendez plus 3 mois.  Réagissez vite consultez… Auourd ́hui les méthodes de dépistage et les possibilités de traitement ont changé... Dans tous les cas vous pouvez prendre conseil auprés de: Sida info service 0800 840 800” English translation of the text: “You have taken a risk, don’t wait three more months [to take the test.]  React quickly and consult … today the methods for testing for AIDS and the possibilities for treatment have changed… In all cases you can seek advice with: AIDS Info Service 0800 840 800.”
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR087.|~|The poster is an information brochure with all kinds of information about AIDS, testing, prevention and treatment. It includes tips on how to deal with a situation when a person takes a chance.|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: Testing for AIDS. What to do today?

Item Title: Homme averti....[inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Preventive medicine|~|Sexually Transmitted Diseases--immunology|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Homme averti....[inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional text in the bottom right of the poster in French: “ Pour en parler Sida Info Service: 0800 840 800 (24h/24 anonyme, confidential et grantuit)”Text English: “To talk about it call AIDS Info Service: 0800 840 800 (24h/24 anonymous, confidential and free)”
Description.note: Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR088.|~|This poster is a collection of colored drawings in a comic book style. These pictures tell a story of a gay man who is looking for love. It resembles a situation comedy, for instance, the hero is watching TV and getting information on different subjects. The story is building up to a conviction that he could have unsafe sex, because in the news he is hearing that scientists have some drugs that improve the immune systems of people with AIDS. When he meets with his partner he ridicules him for trying to use condom; he declares "haven’t you seen the news on TV?" When he learns that his partner does not have TV, he tells him you are so uniformed, how do you get through life?|~|Date on back of poster, 2005, reflects when the vendor received the copy later acquired by the UCLA Library.
Alternate Title.translated: An Informed man...

Item Title: Chaude pisse! [Inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Belgium. Ministère de la communauté française|~|Ex Aequo (Organization)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Chaude pisse! [Inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Vous pissez des lames de rasoir? La Chaude-pisse ou gonorrhée est une IST facilement contagieuse et de plus en plus présente chez les homosexuels masculins. Elle se transmet très facilement par contact direct non protégé avec les sécrétions génitales, anales et orales (fellation, pénétration, baiser profond,...) d'une personne infectée. Le préservatif en duo avec du gel lubrifiant est le meilleur moyen pour se protéger des IST.
Description.note: Translated additional poster text: Do you piss razor blades? The clap or gonorrhea is an easily contagious STI [Sexually Transmitted Infection] becoming more common among homosexual men. It is easily transmitted by unprotected direct contact with genital, and oral secretions (fellation, penetration, deep kissing,...) of an infected person. The best way to protect ones self from STIs is to use a condom with lubricant gel.|~|The poster contains a picture of three razor blades on the top and three pictures of urinals.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE044.
Alternate Title.translated: Clap!

Item Title: Hoe het condoom gebruiken? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Sexually Transmitted Diseases--prevention & control|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|Sexually transmitted diseases--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|Birth control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Hoe het condoom gebruiken? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: For a hundred million reasons ... 1. Scheur de verpakking aan de inkeping open zonder het condoom te beschadigen. Neem het condoom er voorzichtig uit.2. Knijp het reservoire (topje) van het condoom dicht tussen duim en wijsvinger. Zo vermijd je dat er lucht in blijft.3. Plaats het condoom tegen de top van de stijve penis en rol het met de andere hand volledig af.4. Trek na het klaarkomen terug als de penis nog stijf is, terwijl je het condoom vasthoudt.5. Gooi het gebruikte condoom weg in de vuilnisemmer.Sensoa: Praat over seks.Voor persoonlijke vragen over HIV, soa en anticonceptie kan je terecht bij veilig vrijenlijn (078-15 15 15). Meer infor over HIV, soa anticonceptie op www.sensoa.be.|~|Translated poster text: 1. Tear open the package at the notch without damaging the condom. Remove the condom carefully. 2. Squeeze the reservoir (tip) of the condom between your thumb and forefinger. Make sure no air remains. 3. Place the condom against the tip of the erect penis and roll it on completely with the other hand. 4. Pull back after ejaculation while the penis is still stiff, holding the condom. 5. Throw away the used condom in the garbage. Sensoa: Talk about sex. For personal questions about HIV, STDs, and contraception, you can contact the safe sex line (078-15 15 15). More information on HIV, STDs, and contraception at www.sensoa.be.
Description.note: Illustrated instructions of how to effectively use and dispose of a condom.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item BE048.
Alternate Title.translated: How do you use a condom?

Item Title: Lucas ou le secret de l'invisibilité. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Social acceptance|~|HIV infections--Social aspects|~|HIV-positive persons $x Public opinion|~|HIV Infections--Psychology
Personal or Corporate Name.creator: Phung, Christine|~|Creative Syndicate (Firm)|~|Delon, Nicola
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Lucas ou le secret de l'invisibilité. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Gráce á sa découverte révolutionnaire. Lucas s'est imposé en très peu de temps comme un des plus grands gènies du XXIe siècle, pourtant Lucas n'a rien d'un sceintifique mais voila il a découvert le secret de l'invisibilité sans même faire d'expériences ou de calculs compliqués, non du jour ou il a annonce sa seropositivité a son entourage. Il a constaté l'efficacité de sa découverte. L'effet est plus ou moins repide. Les regards changent, les coups de fil s'arrétent. Puis ça y est -- il est devenu transparent. C'est sur Lucas est un genie un vrai. Mais bon il aurait tout de meme préféré trouver un traitement contre le Sida.Le premier traitement, c'est notre solidarite.and"SIDA Grande Cause Nationale 2005"
Description.note: Translated additional poster text: ...Lucas has won his place among the great minds of the the 21st century, despite being unscientific he managed to discover the secret of invisibility without knowledge of experimentation or complicated calculous, all he had to do was announce he was HIV postive to his family. He noted the effectiveness of his discovery. It was more or less immediate. People's looks changed, the calls stopped. That was it -- he was invisible. Certainly Lucas was a true genius. Still he would have preferred to have discovered a treatment to prevent AIDS.The best treatment is our support.Aids the great national cause|~|The picture shows a man opening both his hands, palms up. He is wearing a jacket and pants. Next to the man's picture there is a small article.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR139.
Alternate Title.translated: Lucas, or the secret of invisibility.

Item Title: Regards alternatifs [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: AIDES "Groupes sourds"|~|Crips Île-de-France|~|Photo (Firm)|~|One Vision|~|Bristol-Myers Squibb Company. $b Pharmaceutical Group
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Regards alternatifs [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated poster text: European photography competition 2007. Affected by AIDS and HIV? Fight stigma and discrimination associated with this disease by participating in the photography competition on "alternative look". Send your photos that show how a person living with AIDS sees the negative and vice versa ... Deadline to submit your photos: March 15, 2007. Bristol-Myers Squibb is committed to the fight against AIDS and sponsors the annual photography contest "One Vision" to fight against stigma and discrimination that patients face. 4 European prizes (total: 14 000 €) and numerous national awards (1 000 € each). For more information on the competition and send your photos, visit: www.onevision2007.org|~|Additional poster text: concours europeen de photographie 2007. Concerné par le sida et le VIH? Combattez la stigmatisation et la discrimination liées à cette maladie en participant au concours de photographie sur le thème "regards alternatifs". Envoyez vos photos qui montrent comment une personne vivant avec le sida voit les séronégatifs et vice versa... Date limite pour déposer vos photos : 15 mars 2007. Bristol-Myers Squibb est engagé dans la lutte contre le sida et parraine chaque année le concours de photographie "One Vision" pour lutter contre la stigmatisation et la discrimination auxquelles les patients sont confrontés. 4 prix européens (montant total : 14 000 €) et de nombreux prix nationaux (1 000 € chacun). Pour plus d'informations sur le concours et pour envoyer vos photos, consultez le site: www.onevision2007.org
Description.note: Poster shows a black and white photo of a man with a slightly open mouth, eyes wide, and hands behind his head. He is wearing a plaid shirt. There are other photos pinned up on the wall behind him.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR158.
Alternate Title.translated: Alternative look

Item Title: Sida ne fait pas que des morts. Il fait aussi des orphelins. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sida ne fait pas que des morts. Il fait aussi des orphelins. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated poster text: In 2001, over 13 milion children have lost one or both parents to AIDS ... in 2010, it will be 26 million. Why is it important to take action? These children are exposed daily to malnutrition, deprivation of their property, lack of education, alcoholism, crime ... Left to themselves, they are the target of numerous acts of violence: economic exploitation of their labor, abuse ... Orphans are becoming the main victims of sexual assault and in some countries they are the first enlisted in armed conflict. AIDS orphans are a particularly fragile generation due to being exposed to an early HIV infection. Help us help them.To sponsor an orphan or send donations, contact AIDS Orphans International|~|Additional poster text: En 2001, plus de 13 milions d'enfants ont perdu un ou leurs deux parents des suites du sida... en 2010, ils seront 26 millions. Pourquoi il est important d'agir? Ces enfants sont quotidiennement exposés à des risques vitaux intolérables : malnutrition, privation de leurs biens, déscolarisation, alcoolisme, délinquance... Livrés à eux-mêmes, ils sont la cible de nombreuses exactions : exploitation économique de leur force de travail, maltraitance... Les orphelins deviennent de fait les premières victimes des agressions sexuelles et dans certains pays en guerre, les premiers enrôlés dans les conflits armés. Les orphelins du sida ont une génération particulièrement fragilisée et exposée, à son tour,à une contamination précoce par le vih. Aidez-nous à les aider.Pour parrainer un orphelin ou envoyer vos dons, contactez Orphelins Sida International, 47/49 rue des maraîchers 7502 Paris - France - 01 47 97 54 94
Description.note: Poster shows four cartoon silhouttes of people, three are adults and one is a child. All of them have targets on their chests, however the adults have bullhole like spots around their targets and one of them is missing his head and shoulders.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR163.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS does not just kill. It also orphans.

Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Protégez l’avenir de vos proches, donnez aujourd’hui pour la recherche contre le sida. Appelez le Nº Azur 0 810 588 588[Protect the future of your loved ones, give today to research against AIDS.Call 0 810 588 588]|~|SidactionEnsemble contre le sida.[SidactionTogether agains AIDS]|~|Additional poster text: Lucas pourrait être votre enfant. Et pour le protéger, vous ne pourrez plus faire grand chose.[Lucas could be your child. Your little boy. Today you watch out for his well being. But in 10 years? Like all teenagers, he will be confronted with the risk of AIDS. And to protecting him, there's not much you can do.]

Title: Puceau [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Puceau CH 7EK TTBN laissez date el lieu.-- Puceau mon cul!! S'y avait des puceaux dans le loin on le saurait!!![Virgin in search of 7EK TTBN leave date and place.  Virgin my ass!! If you had virgins one would know it from afar!!!]|~|Additional poster text: Puceau ou pas pour éviter les ruptures de capotes mettez du gel a base d'eau sur le péso et sur le cul.AIDESwww.aides.org[Virgin or not to avoid rubber ruptures put water based gel on the condom and on the assAIDESwww.aides.org]
Description.note: Picture of the wall of a bathroom stall, complete with a big dispensing wheel of toilet paper and grafitti on it and the wheel.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR173.
Alternate Title.translated: Virgin

Item Title: XXL tous les lundis soirs. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: XXL tous les lundis soirs. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: offre réservée aux culs bien dilatés.[offer reserved to well dilated asses]|~|Additional poster text: Petit cylindrée ou gros cube, les corps gros endomagent le préservatif. Utilise toujours du gel a base d'eau.-- AIDESwww.aides.org.[Small cylinder  or big cube, big body parts damage the condom. Always use water based gel. -- AIDESwww.aides.org.]
Description.note: Picture of a white tiled bathroom wall with the drawing of a big size penis in black marker, and other graffitti on it. The message of the poster is written as if it was part of the graffiti, on the bottom left corner.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR174.
Alternate Title.translated: XXL every Monday evening

Item Title: Petit cul serre ch grosse teub [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Petit cul serre ch grosse teub [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: A 2 comme à 10, sache que les manipulations risquent d'endommager la capote. Le préso s'enfile toujours sur une bite en erection en pinçant le réservoir afin d'évacuer la bulle d'air. Si tu le déroules á l'envers prends un autre.[Between 2 or 10, know that manipulations have the risk of damaging the condom. The rubber is always threaded on an erected cock, pinching the reservoir to rid the air bubble . If you unroll it wrong side, get another one.
Description.note: A white wall of what seems to be a toilet stall (there's a horizontal pipe with a roll of toilet paper between it and the wall) with graffitti on it, including the poster message.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR175.
Alternate Title.translated: Tight small ass searches fat pipe

Item Title: Voteriez-vous por moi si j'étais séropositif ? [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: HIV (Viruses)|~|AIDS (Disease)|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome|~|Social acceptance|~|Political participation|~|Political participation|~|HIV
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Voteriez-vous por moi si j'étais séropositif ? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: AIDES www.aides.org|~|Additional poster text: C'est le sida qu'il faut exclure, pas les séropositifs.[It is AIDS that needs to be excluded, not HIV positive people.]
Description.note: A picture of  François Bayrou (a French centrist politician, president of Union for French Democracy (UDF) and a candidate in the 2002 and 2007 French presidential elections.) against a dark backgound with the words "Would you vote for me if I was HIV positive?" and underneath "It is AIDS that needs to be excluded, not HIV positive people.]"|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR180.
Alternate Title.translated: Would you vote for me if I was HIV positive?

Item Title: Me donneriez-vous toujours autant d'affecton si j'étais séropositive? [inscribed]

Description.note: A black and white head-shot of an elderly woman facing to the left and looking to the right with a smile on her face.  Poster alludes to the social aspects people face as far as being discriminated against, feared, and denied affection when diagnosed with HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR190.
Alternate Title.translated: Would you always give me so much affection if I was HIV positive?

Item Title: Vivez assez longtemps pour trouver le bon. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Vivez assez longtemps pour trouver le bon. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: Protect yourself.|~|Additional poster text: Protegez vous.
Description.note: Colorful series of cartoon images that depict short stories in the style of a comic strip.  Exclamatory words (in English) are scattered throughout the images in order to aid in the various stories of the cartoon characters.  The stories revolve around the cartoon characters meeting and engaging in sexual intercourse.  The overall message of the poster is to live life and practice safe sex.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR194.
Alternate Title.translated: Live long enough to find the right one.

Item Title: Je n'oublierai jamais le jour de mon proces. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--psychology|~|HIV infections--Social aspects
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Je n'oublierai jamais le jour de mon proces. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1 séropositif sur 3 est rejeté par sa propre famille.  Stop à l'exclusion.  Quand je suis passé aux aveux ily a eu un long silence gêné dans l'assemblée pour la premiére fois de ma vie, j'ai sentir quel point sa pouvait faire mal d'être juge-onm'a accusé...|~|Translated additional poster text: 1 out of 3 HIV positive people are rejected by their family.  Stop the exclusion.  When I confessed a while ago there was a long awkward silence in the assembly for the first time in my life, it hurt to be accused...
Description.note: Color mural on the side of a wall of the face and shoulders of a sad looking boy with miniature hands pointing at him.    To the right of the boy is the text of a narrative of the boy's experience revealing the fact that he is HIV positive.  To the right of the text is a separate part of the wall with a statistical fact about HIV positive people and family rejection.  Poster alludes to the social aspects people face as far as being discriminated against, feared, and denied affection when diagnosed with HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR195.
Alternate Title.translated: I will never forget the day of my trial.

Item Title: Jack est formidable. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Social aspects|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--psychology|~|HIV infections--Social aspects
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Jack est formidable. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: It was perfect the day I told him that I was HIV positive... 7 out of 10 HIV positive people suffer from loneliness.  Stop the exclusion.|~|Additional poster text:  Il a été parfait le jour oû je lui ai annoncé  que j'etais séropositif. 7 séropositifs sur 10 souffrent de solitude. Stop A L'exclusion.
Description.note: Color mural on the side of a wall of a man holding and using a can of spray paint.  The emission from the spray can is forming the phrase "Jack est formidable".  Below the emission is text of the narrative of the man's experience revealing to a loved one that he is HIV positive.  Below the narrative is text of a statistical fact about HIV positive people and loneliness.  Around the man are images depicting dogs including dog heads with the bodies of humans.  There is also a dog looking at the mural from the sidewalk.  Poster alludes to the social aspects people face as far as being discriminated against, feared, and denied affection when diagnosed with HIV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR196.
Alternate Title.translated: Jack is great.

Item Title: J'ai toujours reve d'etre une actrice. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: J'ai toujours reve d'etre une actrice. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: Stop the exclusion. 2 out of 3 HIV positive people conceal their HIV status for fear of discrimination. I waited, and then one day it happened without me. I played a student funny and carefree...|~|Additional poster text: Stop à l'exclusion. 2 séropositifs sur 3 dissimulent leur séropositivité par peur discriminations.   Et puis un jour c'est arrivé sans que je ne m'y attende. J'ai joue une étudiante drole et insouciante.
Description.note: Color mural on the side of a wall of a woman sitting with her arms folded.  To the right of the woman is an image of a flyer for a play which describes how the woman cannot pursue her dreams of becoming an actress because she constantly has to hide the fact that she is HIV positive.  In between the woman and the flyer there is text of a statistical fact about how people conceal the fact that they are HIV positive.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR197.
Alternate Title.translated: I always dreamed of being an actress.

Item Title: Semaine contre le sida. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Semaine contre le sida. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: From Dec 1 to Dec 8 1993.  Dec 1st: "One Way", dramaticized by a debate and Theatre & Co...|~|Additional poster text: Du 1er au 8 Decembre 93. 1er déc : "Aller Simple", un débat théâtralisé par theatre & Co...
Description.note: Poster for "One Week Against AIDS" in Paris, France.  Poster has a cartoon of a nude couple with cupid hovering above them aiming a condom tipped arrow at them.  Below the cartoon is a list of AIDS prevention related events going on during the week including a brief description and where they are.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR198.
Alternate Title.translated: One week against AIDS.

Item Title: Sida, en parler pour mieux lutter [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--France|~|AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|World AIDS Day|~|HIV infections--Prevention|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sida, en parler pour mieux lutter [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: 1er décembre 2007 - journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida.  La quasi-totalité des postes de travail peut être tenue par des salariés atteints du VIH sans risque pour leur santé ou celle de leurs collègues.  Tu n'as rien oublié ma chérie.|~|Translated Additional poster text: December 1st 2007 - World Day to Combat against AIDS. Almost all jobs can be held by employees with HIV without risk to their health or that of their colleagues. You have not forgotten my dear?
Description.note: Poster advertising the World Day To Combat AIDS on December 1, 2007.  Poster has a cartoon of a man picking up a woman to go on a date.  On the stairwell is the woman's parents reminding her to not forget to use a condom.  To the left and right of the cartoon are HIV statistics in relation to France.  Below the cartoon explains that HIV positive people can be employed in almost every job without risk to themselves or others.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR199.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS, talk to fight better

Item Title: Ne banalisons pas le sida! [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: AIDS (Disease)--Prevention|~|World AIDS Day|~|Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--prevention & control|~|HIV Infections--prevention & control
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Ne banalisons pas le sida! [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: December 1st 2006 - World Day to Combat against AIDS. Hey, what is with your yucky chewing gum! It has what? It is' lubricated. It's full of vitamins to stop AIDS.|~|Additional poster text: 1er décembre 2006 - Journée mondiale de lutte contre le sida.  Dis donc, ils sont dégueu tes chewing gums! C'est a quoi?  C'est au 'lubrifié.  C'est plein de vitamines pour pô attraper le sida.
Description.note: Poster for World Aids Day on December 1st 2006.  Poster has a cartoon of two boys with a box of condoms.  The boy on the left is chewing one of the condoms mistaking it for chewing gum.  The boy on the left is reading the box and saying that the gum is "lubricated".  To the left and right of the cartoon are facts and statistics about HIV and AIDS.  The poster's overall message is that AIDS is not funny and ironically depicts a humorous cartoon about condoms.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR200.
Alternate Title.translated: Do not trivialize AIDS!

Item Title: Vous avez des questions?  Nous avons des réponses. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Vous avez des questions?  Nous avons des réponses. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Résponses en langues étrangeres : anglais, arabe, bambara, espagnol et russe.  Lundi mercredi et vendredi de 14h à 23h.
Description.note: Black and white image of two gay men embracing and kissing.  The poster advertises and lists five different hotlines for people to call for information about AIDS, HIV, and other sexually transmitted diseases.  The phone numbers are listed to the right of the image and a website is listed below the image.  The poster also refers to the fact that the hotline services are in multiple languages.|~|Translated Additional poster text: Answers in foreign languages: English, Arabic, Bambara, Spanish and Russian. Monday Wednesday and Friday from 2pm to 11pm.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR211.
Alternate Title.translated: Have questions?  We have answers.

Title: SIDA : hablar de esto ayuda. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Lunes, Miercoles, Viernes de 14h a 19h, les respondemos en su idioma.|~|Translated additional poster text: Moday, Wednesday, and Friday from 2pm to 7pm, we reply in your language.
Description.note: Poster advertising an AIDS information hotline.  Depicted is a color image of of a man and woman intimately close with the woman's head on the man's shoulder.  Below the image are the days and times the hotline is active as well as what languages are available.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR212.
Alternate Title.translated: AIDS : talking about it helps.

Description.note: Poster depicts a black couple. Man is hugging a woman from the back. Both of them are looking up. Also poster provides information about Sida Info Service, their telephone number, web-site, work hours, and languages, in which they provide their service.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR213.

Item Title: Espace de dialogue 3 types d'entretiens. [inscribed]
Subject.conceptTopic: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome--therapy|~|HIV-positive persons--Conduct of life|~|AIDS (Disease)--Information services|~|HIV infections--Treatment
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Espace de dialogue 3 types d'entretiens. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Le kiosque. Un espace de dialogue 3 types d'entretiens. Anonymes confidentiels et gratuits. Sur rendez-vous. Por lui, elle, pour elle, elles, pour il, ils. Des entretiens d'information et de prévention. Des Entretiens sexualité. Pour les personnes in traitement vih. Des entretiens d'accompagnement à la qualité de vie. Des entretiens sexualité. Une seule adresse.  Un seul numéro.|~|Translated additional poster text: Kiosk. A space for dialogue three types of interviews. Anonymous confidential and free. Appointment. For him, her, her, them, for it, they. Interviews information and prevention. Talks sexuality. For those in HIV treatment. Interviews accompanying the quality of life. Interviews sexuality. A single address. One number.
Description.note: Poster advertising an AIDS information kiosk.  Information is available in multiple languages and for both men and women affected by HIV and AIDS.  The kiosk logo is depicted at the top and the information is listed below along with a phone number and address.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR214.
Alternate Title.translated: Space for dialogue 3 types of interviews.

Item Title: Sexe ça me parle. [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Sexe ça me parle. [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Translated additional poster text: Taking appointments from 10:00am to 1:30pm at Info Kiosk AIDS. You are a man sexually active or would like to be. You have questions about you, she, him, you both: a sex therapist welcomes you by appointment to the point, confidential and free.|~|Additional poster text: Prise de rendez-vous de 10H00 A 13H30 au Kiosque Info Sida.  Vous êtes un homme sexuellement actif ou vous aimeriez l'être. Vous avez des questions, sur vous, sur elle, sur lui, sur vous deux: un sexologue vous reçoit sur rendez-vous pour faire le point, dans un cadre confidentiel et gratuit.
Description.note: Slightly blurry black and white head-shot of a man.  Poster advertises an AIDS information kiosk in Paris.  On the left side of the poster is a description of the services offered by the kiosk, to whom they are offered, and how to make an appointment.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR215.
Alternate Title.translated: Sex works with me.

Item Title: Two penises, one with a condom and one without a condom. [descriptive]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Two penises, one with a condom and one without a condom. [descriptive]
Description.note: Image of two penises, one without a condom and in the manner of the universal symbol for "no".  The other penis is wearing a condom and does not have the "no" sign over it.  The poster suggests that wearing a condom is good and not wearing a condom is bad.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR224.

Item Title: Alerte! LGV. [inscription]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Alerte! LGV. [inscription]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Lymphogranulomatose venerienne. La LGV peut causer de graves infections anales et des organes genitaux. Sont le plus en danger les hommes baisant sans preservatif ou pratiquant le fist sans gant.  La LGV se traite facilement lorsqu'elle est depistee precocement, en cas de doute consulter votre medecin ou SIDA info service.
Description.note: Translated additional poster text: Lymphogranuloma venereum. LGV can cause serious infections of the anal and genital organs. At most risk are men fucking without a condom or practicing fisting without gloves. LGV is easily treated when detected early, when in doubt consult your doctor or AIDS information service.|~|Poster warning people about Lymphogranuloma venereum, or LGV.  The poster describes the causes and effects of LGV on the human body.  There are symbols for "stop", "gloves" and "hospital" accompanying the text describing LGV.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR226.
Alternate Title.translated: Alert! LGV.

Item Title: Capote ou pas entre partenaires stables? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Capote ou pas entre partenaires stables? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Avant de décider, ensemble faites le point sur vos prises de risques passées et dépistez-vous. Abandonner nâtivement la capote au début d'une nouvelle relation n'est pas une preuve d'amour. Ce comportement est la source de nombreuses contaminations.|~|Translated additional poster text: Before you decide, take stock of all your past risk-taking and track yourself. Abandoning the canopy natively to begin a new relationship is not proof of love. This behavior is the source of many infections.
Description.note: Color photo of two gay men early in their homosexual relationship.  They are sitting on a sidewalk and one has his arm around the other.  Poster suggests that early in a relationship one should not have unprotected sex as a proof of love.  One should be aware of their sexual past and what risks they took before engaging in a new relationship.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR227.
Alternate Title.translated: Hood or no stable partner?

Item Title: Besoin de sexe quand ça ne va pas? [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.other: Institute for Prevention and Social Reasearch (Utrecht, Netherlands)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Besoin de sexe quand ça ne va pas? [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Dans ces moments-là, multiplier les rencontres en zappant la capote ne résout rien…Déprime solitude : le preservatif te protégé aussi quand tu es plus vulnerable.
Description.note: Picture of two men kissing, and a separate picture of one man alone, looking depressed.  Text appears to the left.  A condom appears on the lower left.|~|Translated poster text: In such moments getting rid of the condom while dating multiple partners solves nothing.     Depression, loneliness: the condom protects you when you are most vulnerable.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR237.
Alternate Title.translated: Need Sex When Things Go Wrong?

Item Title: On a parfois envie de se dire que baiser sans capote [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.publisher: Syndicat national des entreprises gaies|~|Institute for Prevention and Social Reasearch (Utrecht, Netherlands)
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: On a parfois envie de se dire que baiser sans capote [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: on a parfois envie de se dire que baiser sans capote, ce n'est pas si grave.ne nous racontons pas d'histoires!Un rapport non protégé est un risqué pour toi pour luiLe preservatif vous protege quand le desir vous rend vulnerable
Description.note: Translated poster text: We sometimes want to say, let's fuck without condoms, it's not so bad.We do not tell stories!Unprotected sex is risky for you and for himThe condom protects you when desire makes you vulnerable.|~|A picture of two men in their underwear embracing.  Text appears on the right.  An image of a condom appears on the lower right.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR238.
Alternate Title.translated: We Sometimes Want to Fuck without Condoms...

Title: Je le vis bien [inscribed]

An image of a condom appears on the lower right.  The text runs down the right-hand side.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR239.
Alternate Title.translated: I Live Well

Item Title: GHB = Danger [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.other: Observatoire français des drogues et des toxicomanies  |~|Mission interministérielle de lutte contre la toxicomanie (France)|~|Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: GHB = Danger [inscribed]
Description.inscription: Additional poster text: Jamais de GHB, meme en petite quantité, avant, pendant ou après la consummation d’alcool.Des convulsions pevvent survenir quand le GHB est associé à de l’ecstasy, des tranquillisants ou derives d’amphétamines.Les effets des drogues pevvent vous faire oublier de vous protéger, utilisez toujours des préservatifs.
Description.note: A picture of a cocktail glass with ice and GHB.  A stirrer with a skull on top is in the glass as well.  The text appears underneath the image.|~|Translated poster text: Never consume GHB, even in small amounts before, during or after the consummation of alcohol.Seizures may occur when GHB is associated with ecstasy, tranquilizers or derivatives of amphetamine.The effects of drugs can make you forget to protect yourself, always use condomsThanks to their expertise

Item Title: Viagra + Poppers = Accident Cardiaque [inscribed]
Personal or Corporate Name.repository: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History and Special Collections for the Sciences
Title: Viagra + Poppers = Accident Cardiaque [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text: Viagra (ou tous les medicaments du meme type) + Poppers (arômes) = Accident Cardiaque.Quel que soit ton âge, l’association des ces produits peut entraîner des troubles cardiaques graves pouvant être mortels.Tous les medicaments traitant les problems d’érection sont concernés.|~|Translated poster text: Viagra (or other drugs of a similar type) + Poppers (aromatic) = Cardiac Arrest.Whatever your age, use of these products can cause serious heart conditions can be fatal.All drugs treating erectile problems are of concern.|~|The text is inscribed over a picture of a hand grenade.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR241.
Alternate Title.translated: Viagra + Poppers = Cardiac Arrest

Title: Percute [inscribed]
Description.note: Additional poster text: PercuteBaiser sans capote lorsqu’on est séropo, c’est mettre en danger sa santé.La sur-contamination par une autre souche VIH représente pour toi un risqué reel, de meme que la co-infection par certaines ISTqui se transmettent encore plus facilement entre séropos.Itilise le preservative lors de chaque rapport sexuel que ton partenaire soit séronégatif ou sropositif.  Tu mettra ainsi toutes les chances de ton côté.|~|Translated poster text:Sex without a condom when you are HIV-positive, is endangering his health.The over-contamination from another HIV strain is for you a real risk, as is the co-infection with certain STDs which are transmitted more easily between sero-positives.Use condoms during each sexual intercourse whether your partner is HIV negative or seropositif. Doing so minimizes all your risks.|~|The poster shows photographs scattered on a alluding to sexual activity, along with some condoms and pills.  The poster text appears below.|~|Poster held by Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library. History & Special Collections, Collection no. 306, item FR246.
